Memorandum:

DEPARTMENTAL PURCHASING AGENT

Your file 45 I.A. Outside.

With reference to your memorandum of August 23rd regarding a telephone for the Kettle Point Indian Day School, I attach for your information, completed form "Application for Authority to Install Additional Telephone Equipment", also sketch of the line prepared by Indian Superintendent McCracken.

Bernard E. Neary
Superintendent of Education.

PP/NGD
APPENDIX "A"

APPLICATION FOR AUTHORITY TO INSTALL ADDITIONAL TELEPHONE EQUIPMENT

DEPARTMENT Mines and Resources
BRANCH Indian Affairs Branch
LOCATION Kettle Point Indian Reserve, Rosanquet Township, Lambton County, Ontario.

OFFICER(S) FOR WHOM INSTALLATION IS REQUIRED

Name(s) For use of teachers at Kettle Point Indian Day School.

Classification

Building Teachers' residence, Kettle Point Indian Day School.

Room Number

EQUIPMENT REQUIRED Standard telephone Annual rental charge $20.00

EXPLANATION OF NECESSITY FOR ADDITIONAL EQUIPMENT:

(a) This installation is required to provide service for a newly-appointed officer (or officers). Explain need in detail.

Telephone urgently required in teachers' residence at Kettle Point School due to isolated conditions.

(b) This installation is required to provide additional telephone facilities for an officer (or officers) already serviced. Explain need in detail.

After careful consideration of all the facts, I am convinced that there is no possibility of providing the required service by the use of alternative equipment at a lower cost, re-arrangement of present equipment, or by other means, and that the equipment requested is necessary for the efficient carrying out of duties.

Sept. 10, 1948.

Date Officer in charge

Approved

Deputy Minister

Mr. M.W. McCracken, Supt. of Indian Agency,
Sarnia, Ontario.

With reference to your letter of July 22nd, in connection with providing telephone service at the Kettle Point Teachers' Residence, the Minister has now approved an expenditure of $164.50 for the installation of a telephone at the Kettle Point Teachers' Residence for the cost of the poles, wire, material and labour involved. This was the amount stated in the letter of July 20th from the People's Telephone Company of Forest, which you forwarded to us under cover of July 22nd.

In placing a telephone in the residence, our policy is that the Department provides the original installation costs but the teacher is expected to pay the monthly service charge.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
OTTAWA, Ontario.

Enclosed please find voucher #557 for $15.00 in favour of W. J. McFarlane, Forest, Ontario for three tanks of drinking water supplied for use at Kettle Point School and Teachers' Residence.

On September 9th I visited Kettle Point and found that the well was dry. The new teacher had commenced duties on September 7th and was having great difficulty in procuring drinking water for the pupils and for use in her residence. I considered this an emergency and immediately contacted a white man in Forest who agreed to deliver three tanks of water and put it in the well.

I recommend that the enclosed account be approved and payment made.

M. W. McCracken,
Superintendent, Sarnia Indian Agency.

Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
OTTAWA, Ontario.

There is a small Quebec heater in the junior classroom at Kettle Point Indian Day School. It is no longer serviceable and should be replaced. On a recent visit to the classroom Mr. Doucet and I examined the stove and he instructed me to write to secure authority to purchase a new heater.

I recommend that a small Quebec heater which would burn stove size anthracite coal be purchased. I could secure it locally at an estimated cost of $30.00 and submit the account to the Department for payment.

Please advise if an expenditure as outlined above meets with your approval.

M. W. McCracken,
Superintendent, Sarnia Indian Agency.
October 21, 1948.

Mr. M.W. McCracken,

Sarnia, Ontario.

With reference to your letter of the 15th instant, you may purchase a small Quebec heater, at an approximate cost of $30.00 for use at the Kettle Point School.

Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
OTTAWA, Ontario.

I wish to refer to my letter of October 18th and Departmental reply 401-5 of October 21st, 1948 with reference to the purchase of a small Quebec heater for use in the junior classroom of the Kettle Point Indian Day School.

Before purchasing this stove I discussed the matter with the teacher, Mrs. Clemens. She was quite emphatic in stating that a small Quebec heater of this type has proved unsatisfactory. She is very much opposed to having the present stove replaced by one of a similar type. This teacher recommends the purchase of a larger stove which would hold fire over night. The type of stove which would suit Mrs. Clemens is available in Forest at a cost of $69.50. I agree that the larger stove would be more suitable and if funds are available I recommend the purchase of the more expensive heater.

Kindly advise at an early date as to which stove should be purchased for this classroom.

M. W. McCracken,
Superintendent, Sarnia Indian Agency.
November 10, 1948.

Mr. M.W. McCracken,
Supt. of Indian Agency,
Sarnia, Ontario.

In view of the contents of your letter of the 6th instant, the Department approves the purchase of a stove for the Kettle Point School at a cost of $69.50.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Education Division.

PP/HM.
November 26, 1948.

In past winters it has been customary to provide fresh milk for children attending junior and senior classrooms in Kettle Point School. There is no regular milk delivery on the Reserve with the result that the average child receives very little fresh milk unless it is procured at school.

Last year eight quarts daily were delivered, but the attendance this year is larger. There are eighty-two children enrolled and I think ten quarts per day for the period January to March 31st should be purchased. The Page Dairy at Ravenswood would supply the milk and bill us each month. Milk would be obtained only on the days the school is in operation.

I recommend that the Department approve of supplying fresh milk to Kettle Point school children and an early reply in this connection will be appreciated.

Prophylactic Dental Measures
Kettle Point School

We are forwarding herewith a copy of a letter of 7 May '49 from Miss S. W. Powell, who is our nurse at Sarnia. Miss Powell recommends that tooth brushes, tumblers and tooth powder be made available to Mrs. Mills who is prepared to instruct the children at the Kettle Point School with respect to the care of their teeth.

We understand that you will provide the tooth brushes and tumblers. There are two dental powders available through Indian Health Services supply. One of these contains sodium perborate but we are not in favour of the regular use of this since it may, after continuous use, set up some irritation. The other powder contains camphorated chalk and is much more suitable for regular use. We will suggest that Miss Powell prepare a requisition for sufficient quantity of this tooth powder, although we would anticipate that in due course the students or their parents will find themselves in position to provide this material for themselves.

When the Director and Regional Supervisor J. E. Morris visited this Agency on May 30th I was advised that funds are available to erect a new school on Kettle Point Reserve. Mr. Morris instructed me to write to the Department on this subject.

I have made some preliminary investigation in this connection and beg to report as follows:

As the initial step, additional land should be secured to enlarge the present school site. I think about one (1) acre would be sufficient and could be purchased from Moses Wolfe Sr., who is the recognized owner of most of the lands in the East half of Lot 2, Range "B" immediately east of the existing school lot. The probable cost would be $50.00. It would have to be fenced, clay fill put in and levelled.

I understand that the Department plans to erect a single classroom with full basement as a separate unit rather than build an addition to the existing two-roomed structure. If funds are available I suggest that a small residence be built in conjunction with the proposed new
classroom as the residence now in use will not be large enough to accommodate three teachers.

With regard to water supply I have been informed by reliable Indians that we would be certain to procure a good supply of pure water if a well were drilled to a depth of about eighty feet. Then an electric pumping system and modern plumbing with a septic tank could be installed. At present there is a very poor dug well about thirty-five feet deep at the school, but it goes dry almost every summer. Hydro is available and has been used in the existing school and teacher's residence for the past two months.

There are at least two good Indian carpenters on the Reserve who are capable of erecting the proposed school according to plans and specifications. They are Grant Milliken and Wilfred Shawkence. Both are quite anxious for the work, particularly Milliken. He has built one or two houses in the nearby town of Forest, repaired and renovated stores and built and repaired houses on the Reserve. If either of these two Indians were given the job I believe they would wish to do it on the hourly basis at rates of $1.00 or $1.25 for foreman and carpenters and about 75¢ or 80¢ per hour for labourers. I strongly recommend that the erection of the school be done by contract rather than by day labour for obvious reasons.

The classroom should be large enough to accommodate up to thirty-five pupils. The teacher's residence could be on one end or side of the classroom or above it in the form
of an apartment.

It would appear advisable to have Mr. Doucet or some senior official from the Education Division come to Sarnia to decide upon the location, type and size of building, etc., and then have blueprints prepared for the contractor to follow.

Your advice and instructions in this matter will be appreciated.

M. W. McCracken,
Superintendent, Sarnia Indian Agency.

Re: Erection of New School - Kettle Point Reserve.

I wish to report further with regard to drilling a well for the new school at Kettle Point and in this connection beg to refer you to your letter 401-5 of June 22nd, 1949.

On Monday afternoon, June 27th I made a trip to Forest and Kettle Point to interview well drillers. The only driller in the Kettle Point area is Mr. Frank Rendle, Forest, Ontario. Another driller named Andrew Heal of Watford, Ontario (about twenty miles from Kettle Point Reserve) customarily does considerable well drilling in the Forest district. I did not see Mr. Heal but had a personal interview with Mr. Rendle. I was reliably informed that both of these drillers have adequate drilling machinery and that their work is satisfactory.

Mr. Rendle is of the opinion that it would be necessary to drill to a depth of approximately ninety-five feet to procure water on the school site. He charges $1.25 per foot when drilling through clay, shale or sand,
etc. If he encounters hard pan rock the charges are $1.50 per foot. The well would require 4" casing which would cost approximately $1.30 per foot. The casing is in short supply but Mr. Rendle believes that a dealer in Petrolia, Ontario will have the quantity required in about two weeks from this date. Mr. Rendle is willing to commence drilling operations in about two weeks as soon as he finishes two small jobs on which he is now engaged. However, he pointed out that there would be little use of starting to drill if the casing is not available.

From the above you will note that the estimated cost will be about $260.00. If a dry hole were encountered this cost would be doubled. The cost would also be increased if the driller had to drill beyond the estimated ninety-five feet. On the other hand it is possible that he might strike a good supply of water at eighty or eighty-five feet. In view of the uncertainty of the final cost I did not instruct Mr. Rendle to commence. In any event he could not start until about July 11th.

Would you please give the above consideration and advise any further action which you wish taken in connection with well drilling for the proposed school on Kettle Point Reserve?

M. W. McCracken,

The Kettle Point school and teachers' residence requires interior and exterior painting. The work is not exactly urgent, but if funds are available I recommend that it be performed this year.

I have secured an estimate of the cost from an experienced Indian painter. He will paint the outside of the entire building, which consists of two classrooms and the teachers' residence, with two coats for $325.00. This would include the cost of the paint as well as labour. The estimated cost of the paint which he will use is $110.00 with the labour being $215.00. The first coat would be put on with brush and the second coat with either brush or spray equipment.

The interior painting of the senior classroom for materials and labour for one coat would cost $170.00, being $80.00 for paint and $90.00 for labour. Painting of the interior of the junior room would cost $55.00, being $20.00 for paint and $35.00 for labour.

If the Indian who submitted the estimate is given the contract for this work he would replace a number of
broken window panes and also oil the floor of each classroom at no extra cost. This man has painted quite a number of public schools in white localities in the surrounding township and I am certain that he would do a good job. The interior of the teachers' residence does not require painting this year as it was redecorated last summer.

Would you please advise if you wish to have this work done, and if so an accountable advance cheque for $550.00 in favour of Sarnia Indian Agency Trust Account should be forwarded to cover cost of materials and labour. If you decide that only the exterior of the building is to be painted only $325.00 would be required.

The Indian who submitted the estimate is Sam Greenbird. He would employ three or four other Indian members of the Band to assist him and thinks that it would take about three weeks to complete the project. No action will be taken in connection with this painting until I am further advised.

On visiting Kettle Point School last evening I found that a number of window panes have been broken in the classrooms and teacher's residence since school closed in June. The two outdoor toilets are in need of cleaning. Various other small repair works are required consisting of replacing broken boards on woodshed and garage, fixing latches and locks on doors, screening on windows, etc. If we are not successful in securing water for the proposed new school a new pump will have to be purchased to enable us to get water from the present dug well.

It is difficult to estimate the cost of attending to these repairs, but I think that $75.00 should be sufficient for labour. I therefore suggest that an accountable advance cheque for $75.00 be forwarded in favour of Sarnia Indian Agency Trust Account so that I will be able to pay the Indian labourers as soon as the work is completed. The materials required for the repair work would consist mainly of screening, window panes, and, of course, a pump if it is found to be necessary at a later date. These purchases could be made locally to good advantage and accounts submitted to the Department under cover of vouchers for payment. I do not propose to replace the broken
window panes until the last week in August or the first week in September as they would no doubt be broken again by rowdy youths who congregate around the school and sometimes appear to derive pleasure from damaging property. I might mention that both the Indian Constable and the Royal Canadian Mounted Police in Sarnia have been instructed to keep close watch on the building during the summer holidays when the teacher is absent.

Kindly advise if the repairs as suggested above meet with your approval.

Now, respectfully wish to call the attention of the Department to the following
points:

1. Although it cannot be denied that, in Miss Lahaye's (the former
teacher) time, the Lake Helen Mission school was poorly attended,
yet it is a fact (as the returns of this quarter will show) that, since this
Murphy took charge of it on September 2nd last; the attendance has much improved and surpassed that of the school on the Reserve. Last month I visited the Lake Helen school twice, once I found 12 pupils present, and the other time 10.

While at Lake Helen there are 15 children of school age, at the Reserve there are but 12. Of these latter, six (6) have been away from the Reserve away in the bush ever since last fall, and will not, in all probability, be back till before May or June even. Of the six remaining pupils, one at least, Miss Angelique de Laronde, used not to be taught in the school nor even otherwise by the teacher, Mr Deschamps, but privately at home by her uncle, Mr Henry de Laronde (and such is now sadly the case yet); consequently the teacher could not put her on his return list. Moreover: When last month I was at the Reserve (Wepigon), I asked the teacher, on the second day, whether he would be at his school that afternoon, as I wished to visit it. He answered in the negative, adding, "Whom shall I teach? There are no pupils; you took the best away" (he was alluding to two girls that went to the Lake Helen school, their parents having removed thither).

These being the facts, why would the Department close a school (that of Lake Helen) which is picking up, and is the last at Wepigon, while it keeps open one that has a smaller attendance, and has been established much later.

If the Lake Helen Mission school be closed, where will the children go for their schooling? Up to the Reserve? But there are at least four miles, if not more, between the two places, a distance which has to be made in canoe (on Lake Helen) in summer, and on the ice in winter.
I cannot believe that the Department would insist that the children should go that distance (without speaking of the danger of the route) twice every day, five days every week. Why! this very question of distance and danger was the main reason the Reserve people put forward to get a school of their own, some years ago; and they probably got it too on that very score too.

Will they go to the public school, at Nepigon village, some two miles off? This would require them either to cross Lake Helen, or else the bridge of the C.P.R., over the Nepigon River, almost all of them. Neither of these two alternatives would be without danger for the children, and I do not think that their parents would let them go under such circumstances. Besides we like our Catholic children to frequent a separate school.

There are in the Nepigon, i.e., Red Rock Band, just 37 children of school age—Catholic children (there are no others)—they are divided thus:

- At Lake Helen Mission: 15
- On the Reserve: 12
- At the mouth of the Nepigon River (amboispan): 6
- On White Hill (12 miles from town): 4

Total: 37

I am confident, dear Sir, that the Department will give this matter the consideration it deserves, and decide according to the best interests of the Band.

Yours, dear Sir,

Very respectfully yours,

Jos. Specht, SS.

Kinzy,
in charge of Nepigon Mission.

Dear Sir,

There are a few points about which I would like to have an understanding with the Department:

About the recommendation to the dismissal of teachers:
Ever since the schools of Michipicoten River, Red River, Red Bay, and Nepigon Lake (Jackfish Lake) have been granted, with a salary of $250.00 per year as teacher's salary, we, the missionaries of Fort William, have had the privilege of nominating, or rather recommending teachers, to be approved by the Department; and it was understood that such teachers needed no certificate in the sense the word is understood for teachers among the Indians. With regard to the dismissal of the same, I think that our request to have objectionable teachers removed from position, ought to be taken into consideration, as we are able to form an adequate judgment of the situation. Now dear sir, let me well known—because I well expressed wish to have the school of Paps Plat & that of the Red Rock Reserve removed, Mr. Smith, who knows perfectly well my grounds for complaint, has retained those two teachers in their position, to the utter disgust of

Indians of those two lands. After all the teachers are for those people and not vice versa.

2) About the Lake Helen Mission school? Isn't the intention of the Department to close it finally at the end of the present quarter? Mr. Donnelly told me so by word of mouth only. I would certainly have been very thankful to the Department for a written notice to that effect.

I must confess that the decision surprised me. Believing (in your letter to me no. 153816, 27th Dec. last), you said:

"... In reference to the proposed closing of the Indian school at Lake Helen Mission... I beg to say that enquiry will be made in regard to this matter."

Was the enquiry made? Did Mr. Donnelly make his report? Was the latter favorable to the above school, or unfavorable?

About these points I am left in the dark entirely. I am afraid the Department was not properly enlightened on the state of the Lake Helen or the Red Rock Reserve schools; for, as far as I am concerned, I have always found it fair in its dealings.

3) About the Michipicoten River school... On the 1st inst., Indian Agent Van Abbott, of Baillie-St. Marie, wrote me thus about it: "I am instructed by the Dept's Chief General of Indian Affairs, Ottawa, to inform you, in reply to your letter, that the Department having no available funds for a school at Michipicoten, they cannot contribute anything towards..."
the payment of a teacher's salary" (Letter book 718, file 16450, 6th May 1896).

From the wording of the above, one would infer that the Department is under the impression that there is question of opening for the first time a school at Michipicoten, while there is only question of re-opening one that has been granted by the Department some 15 years ago (though, through incontrollable circumstances, it was in operation only one year - 1882-3).

This is clear from the following words written me by the late Bishop Jervis in March 1887: "I am sure that by this time you know that everything has been granted concerning the four Indian schools at Red Rock, Nepigon Lake (Jackfish), etc., Michipicoten."

The same your non predecessor in office - Mr. Van Horne - implicitly acknowledged (for he knew it) when he wrote me (no. 16450, 17th March, 1892): "No appointment of a teacher at the above point (Michipicoten) could be made until the school house has been removed and ready for use."

Mr. Van Abbott knows all this. Why he has not said anything about it, he knows best.

Hope, dear Sir, in the interest of the Michipicoten Band, which is composed of intelligent people, that you will come to their help in this matter, as they really deserve it.

Hoping to receive an early reply to this my letter, I remain,

Dear Sir, - Your obedient servant, Jos. Specht, J.M.

Donnelly sent her to take charge temporarily of the Rays Plat Reserve school, with the distinct understanding that she was to return to her own at Lake Helen.

Accordingly, some three weeks ago, when away from here & not having heard yet that Mr. Donnelly was no more Indian Agent, I wrote to Mrs. MacKay to return & take her Lake Helen school which she promised to do. So, I expect her to be at the latter school by the 1st of next month, to resume her work.

I also wrote East for another teacher for Rays Plat Reserve, as said school will be left vacant by the departure of Mrs. MacKay.

As to news about the school at Pic River: On November 27th last, Mr. J. P. Donnelly informed me that he had applied to the Depart...
ment for a box stove for that place, also a galvanized iron chimney... but that the Department declined the application on the ground that they had no funds available for that purpose. That he was further instructed to put the school in as good repair as possible for the winter.

At the same time he asked me to stop the teacher, with whom I had been corresponding, from coming to Pic River, as the room could not be kept without a stove, besides being unsafe without a chimney.

The consequence is that the poor children of that Reserve have been without schooling during the last six months. The fact of the matter is that with another stove & a good roof-jack, the building will not be in danger from fire.

Now Mr. Antoine Morissette, one of the residents (half breed) of Pic River offered to furnish the necessary articles, viz.: a stove 3 ft long, a roof-jack, stove-pipes with a damper, as he says "for the sake of the school".

I can get a teacher for that school at any time, and a good one too. For the last half year the people have been clamoring for one. I hope the department will accede to their laudable wishes soon.

I am informed by Indian Agent Van Abbott that the Department has changed its mind, and decided not to grant a teacher for the Michipicoton-River school. I feel sorry for the poor children!

In the hope of receiving an early favorable answer,
I remain, dear sir,

Your obedient servant

Sir,

In answer to yours No. 153816/1 dated May 28th I have to say that Father Laramache being away and believing myself untried, I refused the school. It has been closed for two days after which Father Laramache closed it again on the ground that the agent could not have forwarded his letter.

So once more I ask whether having no money I cannot come away.

I was not fighting for the poor position I was fighting for principles, but I see how useless would be for me to stay on my ground. But as it would pain me to believe that doubt may be entertained in my sincerity I will in due time expose the whole thing in an open letter to Hon. Sir W. Ainslie, during the next session perhaps.

It may interest you to hear that out of the total number of children attending school nine were away hunting fishing and 15 remained who should attend. With that number I had 13 the first day and 12 the next and this after I had left.
The parents perfectly agree to await till further arrangements had been made before sending their children.

I spent the evening in Nipigon with Mr. Hopkins and I am sorry to state that while we were talking about 9.30 P.M., a telegram came to him from his home in Erinsville (New Kingston) that his mother was dying and to hurry home. Have you ever been at Lake Helen? If not I am sure you would enjoy a holiday fishing on the Nepigon River and could visit our school at the same time. Until now the building was a very small and dingy one, but now owing to the repairs Mr. Hattie Couture is having made it will be quite comfortable and respectable looking. Part of the interior, although over forty years old, has never been painted. Of course no white teacher has ever lived in the dwelling and most of the Indian teachers, even, boarded with some of their friends. So there was really never a great need of having any work done.

Getting the lumber for the new kitchen was quite a task. It had to be brought by freight from Port Arthur, then by truck to the boat landing across Lake Helen in a canoe, and on a jumper from the lake to the school.

There is quite a difference between the Indians here and those among whom I have worked until now, but I like working among them. In some ways it is like
Beginning all over. They have no gardens, no stock, horses, nor even poultry. The children are quite proud of their school garden produce.

Many of the Indians tried to discourage me last spring by telling me that nothing would grow. In spite of all their predictions we had quite a garden.

Only a day or two ago I wrote to Mr. Phelan asking his advice and help, if necessary, to start a Penny Bank.

The people and even children here seem to have more money to spend than those east. All last year I spoke to the young men, who spend their evenings in the school, about placing at least a little of their earnings in a bank. Talking the matter over with Miss Griffit this vacation she advised me to try the Penny Bank. She tells me it works well at her school. I shall be pleased to do the extra work required if it teaches them to save.

You spoke of yours of the 19th instant about the Indians returning to Red Rock. I fear this will never come to pass. The Fathers in charge of this Mission have for years tried
To get them to move to the reserve. This place is too near town where they are under influence which is anything but good, but the Indians like this place and the pleasures they find in town and are determined to remain. It is for this reason I give the class-room to the young men in the evening and spend my time teaching music, reading, arithmetic and singing. Besides I have several musical instruments and games for their amusement. Many of the young men have given up their evening in town for those in school. I hope to get more of them this year.

Some of the Indians from the reserve think of moving here. They are afraid of a dam that has been built some miles above the reserve.

Hoping that you will be able to come to see me at Lake Helen before long, I remain

Most gratefully yours,

Elizabeth Lurie

Dear Sir,

After writing to you a few days ago, concerning a letter, I was told that Paul Cameron was sending to the Department. I was told that he had written two letters, one concerning which I wrote, explaining matters, the other complaining of being obliged to send his child to school when she was sick.

From what I am told, he is going around trying to get signatures for both letters.

Lake Helen [signature]
Papigon, Ont.
Jan. 23, 1928
This man, Peter Bouchard, the constable, told me that he is trying to get some of the old men who cannot read, nor know what the letters are about to sign.

This thing happened last year also when they had trouble in the reserve about the pulpwood. One of the men gave a dance and then asked all our young people who went to sign a letter. Not one of them knew what the letter was about. This I am sure of because when I questioned them not one could tell me, said they signed because they were in David Deschamps house and he asked them to sign.

Now the complaint that the children are obliged to come to school, even when ill, is not true.

Nearly everyone of my pupils like to come to school and sometimes do come when they are really sick.

I have a thermometer in the class-room and when I find a child not looking right take its temperature.
A number of times I have had to send some home because they were too sick to be in school.

Paul Cameron's girl is a big strong child, but lazy. Besides her father keeps her home for the least inconvenience, often without the least excuse. As he often told me he is afraid that she would get sick and he would have to spend his money to get the doctor.

He is the one man of this mission who looks after his money.

It seems that he suggested, in his letter, that the government send a doctor around each month to look after the health of the people. There is no cause whatever for this.

True native persons have had to go to the hospital since last June but this is because the doctor in Regina is not competent. I take care of the minor ills of the people. If there is anything serious nothing but going to Port Arthur can be done.

Hoping that this explanation is satisfactory,

Respectfully yours,
Elizabeth Lewis.

Dear Sir,

Owing to a letter which we have just received from Mr. Burke, Indian Agent, complaining that we been too careless about causing our children to attend school regularly, and further advising us that in future we must at first obtain a certificate from a doctor before any child could be excused from attending school on account of being sick.

And also owing to the fact that we have at times had misunderstanding between us and the teacher and Truant officers.

There has been quite a lot of sickness among us including many of our school children this year, and many of us were obliged to be sent up to the nearest hospital for proper care and treatment, and several of our children had to be sent away as the result of trying to force them to continue to travel when they were sick.

We are living in a place where a competent doctor could not always be obtained in time when our children are being sick, consequently we have been obliged to send some of our children to school until such sickness has developed into serious complications before the doctor could arrive here to certify that the children were too sick to attend school.

In this manner several of them had to be sent away to the hospital in a dangerous state and took a great deal of time and considerable expense before they could be restored to their former health.

As much as we appreciate the benefit that the school is doing to us and our children, we can neither neglect to consider our children's safety nor forget to safeguard their health in such circumstances.

We are all grateful for all the good that the Department is doing for us by placing a school where our children could learn something and bearing this in mind, we wish to be understood that we never have any willful intention to keep our children away from school without any grave reason.

Begging that you will consider our situation and closing with promises that we shall do our best to comply with the school regulation.

We have also been reminded by the Indian Agent of the expense that the Department is obliged to put up with in connection with the school as to the amount fuel and lighting consumed, and other things in order to furnish school facilities we wish to advise that most of the fuel and lighting expense is due to the teacher keeping the place open until late hours for the amusement of the young and grown up people as the place is kept open every night until as late as eleven o'clock at night.

Yours faithfully,

Sir,

Re: Patrol to Parmacheen I.R., Lake Helen Indian Mission, Sand Point, I.R. & MacDiarmid, Ont., Assistance to Dept. of Indian Affairs.

First Report:

I have the honour to report that on the morning of the 9th inst; accompanied by Const. Kendall J, I left Fort William by G.P.Ry at 6.05 and proceeded to Nipigon, Ont., and to Lake Helen Indian Mission. I found as is usual at this time of the year most of the men were away hunting. Miss Joyce, the teacher had no complaints with regard to the children with the exception of two children who were not attending school as they should. Notices were served on the parents of Albert Ray and Paul Cameron by Const. Kendall and the parents were warned that they would be punished if their children did not attend school regularly. They promised to send the children to school the following day. The teacher was instructed to notify me if these children did not attend school.

On the same day Parmacheen I.R., situated on the same lake and distant some four miles across the lake, was visited. Most of the Indians were away hunting. The Indians at this reserve have organized a small school and have a local Indian girl teaching. The Indians pay the teacher themselves. No disorderly conduct was reported during the patrol. There appears to be very little sickness among these Indians.

The following morning accompanied by Const. Kendall I left Nipigon by C.N.Ry at 5.26am and proceeded to Varlanger on Lake Nipigon arriving at 7.30am. From Varlanger I proceeded on foot to the Sand Point I.R. I visited the day school and found that the teacher Miss Joyce had complained regularly of attendance. She told me that she had to send about half the children home as about that number were suffering from the disease and are being treated. I also visited the house of the Seneway who has a son dying of Tuberculosis. This house had been reported to me as being in a bad state by the travelling matron. I found that some work had been made since the visit of the matron to assist the Seneway family to get the place cleaned properly, as there was still opportunity for improvement. Most of the men have been away since the freeze up trapping and there were no reports of recent sickness owing to the fact that MacDiarmid is now deserted since the close of the fishing season last week or so the ice season commences at MacDiarmid and a considerable number of men who are away at present will return and then this locality will need watching.

After lunch at the Indian constable's house at Sand Point, I proceeded to MacDiarmid and found this place quiet. I left MacDiarmid with Const. Kendall that evening and returned to Fort William arriving there on the morning of the 11th inst. Mileage as follows: Train 230 miles, on foot 20 miles.

I have the honour to report,

Sir,

your obedient servant,

Dear Mr. Phelan,

From your letter which I have just received I see that my requisition must have been lost so I am enclosing a duplicate.

Last fall I wrote asking you for two maps, one of North America and one of Ontario, both to be on spring rollers as they have to be hung one above the other. I received the two maps but neither on spring rollers. I can manage by having the one of North America underneath. The map of Ontario is not at all suitable for our school. It has all the automobile roads and other important roads etc., of Old Ontario and only a small inset on much reduced scale of our end of the province.

Our grown up men use the map almost as much as the pupils for looking up trapping lines etc. The new map is of no use to them. What we need is a map giving the most important railroads and new Ontario on the same scale as Old Ontario.

Could the map I have be returned and exchanged for another on spring rollers? I have not yet used it.

Perhaps you have heard through Mr. Burk that Lake Helen School has had to turned into a sort of Sanitorium.

For quite a long time I noticed that some of the pupils were not well. About two months ago one of the oldest girls had to go to the hospital for skin disease. After examination she was declared to have T.B. Just before Xmas another had to see a doctor with the same result. I then asked Mr. Burk's permission to have all those whom I found below the mark examined with the result that
for more have the same disease and two others are suspicious. Several others live in homes where persons have lately died of T.B., so that more than half of the class seems to be infected.

Dr. Quackenbush says that none are beyond cure but that they would need plenty of fresh air and nourishing food. Mr. Burk has supplied us with eggs, milk, fruit and vegetables for them.

As all of the children are more sure of the proper care at school than at home we are keeping them here. I am teaching only half periods and have them out in the fresh air the rest of the time. Every morning and afternoon they get a lunch in our kitchen. They bake bread and prepare all they use. After three weeks of this treatment many show marked improvement already.

While at Fort Arthur after New Year I asked several other doctors if there were any danger to the other pupils if these are kept in school. They all said that as long as the sick do not cough etc. and all is kept in very good order there is no danger whatever.

As the three entrance pupils are among the sick I doubt if they will be able to pass. They have ambition enough but they cannot have time enough to finish the work. Fresh air is more important for them than studies just now. While those under treatment are out playing I can work with backward pupils and get these up to the mark in lessons.

The next time there is occasion for me to write I hope to be able to give a better report of the school.

Most respectfully yours,

Jan. 8, 1931

Dear Sir,

There are a few points which I would like to bring to the notice of the Department.

A few days ago I had quite an argument with some of our Indians. The trouble began over clothing sent by Mr. Burk for distribution to destitute Indians.

In the first place, Mr. Burk, when he had a field day and election last October, brought a large quantity of clothing to be distributed among needy Indians. As he was surrounded by men and women many that are not poor as well as the destitute received a good supply. Still he had quite a few pieces left which he asked me to take to the school and distribute later or use as prizes as I wished.

The very next day Michel Datta, the newly elected councillor came to know...
where the articles were which Mr. Burk had left behind. I told him what I had been able to do, never dreaming that he was not satisfied with this arrangement.

As Mr. Data is a new man in office, he was at once besieged with applications for help. Mr. Burk, knowing that I am well acquainted with the needs of our people, each time answered Mr. Data that he would have to investigate first and then sent the letter of request to me to know what I thought of it.

Though I have always been extremely careful not to let the Indians find out about this arrangement, knowing that it causes a lot of trouble, it seems that, either they did find out or only suspect that this is the case.

For my part I find Red Rock Band Indians very thriftless and always trying to get what they need without work. Some of them make quite a sum of money during the summer months when they act as guides to C.P.R. tourists.

With most of them the money is spent as fast as earned. Ever since I came I have tried, by all sorts of means, to teach...
them to save part of their earnings for times of need. When I do not succeed in persuading them to save, I refuse to help them when they run short of funds.

Often when I saw them spend money foolishly, I warned them and tried to show them how foolish they are. Very naturally some persons do not like to be shown that they are wrong.

Michel Datta, of course, feels that since he is counsellor, all his requests should be granted and he very much resists the idea of anyone interfering with his office.

To make matters worse, we had trouble over Cod Liver Oil.

Each fall when ordering the supply of coal oil, gasoline etc., for the year I also ask for the winter's supply of Cod Liver Oil. Mr. Burk brought five gallons C.L.O. with him at the same time as the goods for the field day and asked Mr. Datta to bring it to school. Instead he took it to his own home. Mr. Burk wished me to insist on its being brought to me but I suggested that as Mr. Datta seemed to like distributing it, he should take charge of it. In a short time I was told the oil was being fed to dogs.
I cannot say if this report is true but do know that the amount that lasted me nearly all winter lasted him less than two months. When Mr. Burk came with Miss Inge he brought another five gallons and again Mr. Data who met him at the station to bring it to the school but it again went to his home. As this oil belonged to the nurse she insisted on having it brought to the school and as I did not wish to have any of it fed to dogs I sent a boy for the oil. Of course Mr. Data became more offended.

When Mr. Data wrote complaining about the clothing I had on hand Mr. Burk sent him a supply. I was later told that they had been given to his relatives and friends rather than to the needy. In some instances I knew that this was the case.

When Mr. Burk brought the nurse, Miss Inge, he informed me that he intended sending me some clothing for the poor. I refused to accept them because there is always trouble. These people are very jealous. After I heard a number of complaints about Mr. Data's way of distributing clothing I wrote Mr. Burk saying that I would accept the ones he wished to send.
They arrived on the last day of the year.

As I knew that all had received a supply of clothing I was in no hurry to open the bags. I intended doing so after the holiday and give what I thought would be needed and store the rest for use later on. I always keep a supply on hand as sometimes someone gets sick and has to be taken to the hospital or for some other reason needs better clothing than he has and I am glad to have some to give.

Besides the more these people get the more they want and then do not take care of what they have but throw them out when torn instead of mending them. To give an example of this—two years ago I had the older pupils knit long stockings for their fathers for winter. Two months later I picked up one pair out of the snow that had been thrown out town. Took them home and after washing and ripping them I knit a pair of stockings for one of the children of the same family. Of course this was done to teach all a lesson.

To come back to the clothing, I had no idea that anyone was displeased about the clothing until I was told a few days ago that Daniel Doba had called a meeting to condemn me for this and, as he said, interfering in his work among other things he tried to persuade...
the Indians to send me away. The letter writer and better instructed, of course, objected. Another meeting was held the following evening with the same result.

The next night, which was last Tuesday, the 6th, I called a meeting. I thought it best to talk matters over with them and let them make whatever charges they liked so I could answer them and give them my reasons for acting, not because I fear them, but to let them see that I did not fear to face any of their charges. No one had a word to say and I had to almost challenge Mr. Data to say anything.

Among other things he had told the Indians when he tried to persuade them to send me away that another school where I had taught the Indians had written to the Department and that the Department had sent me away.

I told him and all that this was a lie. I asked him to prove all his statements. The only answer I could obtain was that the Indians said so. Some of those present were so displeased with Mr. Data that they several times interrupted him to tell him that they had never said a word. A number came to me even before I called the meeting to tell me that they were dissatisfied with Mr. Data's actions. All agree that he is simply upset because he has not all
I explained to the Indians, at the meeting, that I am here not simply to teach the children but more especially to help the grown-ups to lead better lives and to help them, that is, to educate them to become respectable citizens, men and women who would be able to support themselves and not be a burden to the government or those about them. I told them that teaching the children is only a small part of my work, and that work done for the good of the older Indians is much appreciated by the Department. To some present this seemed a new idea. They took all I did for them for granted without giving it a thought; several spoke of my care of the sick etc., after that.

For one thing, it seems to me the people here get too much assistance. The people in Manitoulin Island and that part of Ontario get, one might say, very little help and they do not expect it and get along just as well. Mr. Burk is very kind and does not like to refuse anyone so many impose on him. These think they should all get help. I told them the other evening that I considered only three families deserving of help from the Department.
What I would be very grateful for from the Department is this.

I would like to have you write Mr. Data and tell him that his statement, that I had been sent away from a former school by the Department, is a lie.

He should call a meeting and read the Department's letter to the Indians.

At the same time if the Department would tell him that they approve of my action of giving help only when really needed and not to all, at any time, when they know that I have clothing etc.

Also that the Department approves of my trying to induce them to become more thrifty and self-supporting.

This action of the Department would quiet Isabel Data and his friends and would be a great help to me in my work.

Thanking you in advance for this favor.

Yours,

Elizabeth Lewis

Sir:

Re:- Investigation amongst the Indians at Helen Lake

First Report:
On the 14th inst I received a communication from
J.G.Burk - Indian Agent, Fort Arthur, Ontario requesting an
investigation at Helen Lake, Pamachee Indian Reserve where the Indian School was located. A statement had been made
at an Indian Council meeting by one of the Councillors named
Michael Daba to try and force the Indians to put in a general
complaint to make the teacher resign at the Indian School. The
statement was as follows:- "That the Indian Department had
requested the resignation of the School Teacher named Miss
E.Leuch".

The above statement being absolute untrue in so far
as the Indian Department was concerned, we were asked to
investigate in this matter.

I proceeded to Lake Helen where the Indians are
residing. I interviewed Miss E.Leuch on the subject who stated
that Michael Daba had made this statement not knowing as to
what he had said. She stated that he was not very friendly
with her, as trouble arose over the distribution of clothing
sent to the Indians by the Department and elsewhere. This Indian
was a newly appointed Councillor last summer, and having this
authority was urged by the Indians to handle this clothing for
them, so took it upon himself to approach Miss Leuch and force
her to hand over the clothing for distribution. He made several
trips to the school in his manner molesting the school teacher
but she held her ground, and would not give him the clothing.
She told him that she had been given instructions by the
Department to handle the clothing amongst all needy cases,
and it was up to him to help her to locate the needy cases.
Miss Leuch informed me that if this Indian Michael
Daba obtained the clothing, he would just give it out to all his
friends and relations, and others would starve.

On interviewing Michael Daba he stated that he only
told them at the meeting what he had heard Ignatius Pellier
and Mrs Paul John say. They told him that they came from Spain
between Saulte St Marie and Sudbury, that they knew this
teacher at this point, and she had been requested to resign
as school teacher for the Department at that point. Daba said
he did not know whether this was true or not, but as he had
had a little dispute with her over the clothing, he told all
the Indians as to what he had heard.

Acting upon authority of J.G.Burk - Indian Agent I
suspended this Indian Michael Daba for two weeks as Councillor
until the 1st February until the investigation is completed.

Sir:

I beg to report I have just returned from Lake Helen Day School. The teacher, Miss Leusch, reports several families have left for their fishing grounds and taken their children with them. From information obtained from the North West Mounted Police, and reliable Indians, I find in some cases Indians were obliged to have their families accompany them as it was impossible to provide food for their children if they remained on the Reserve.

The situation is extremely hard to cope with, and it is very hard to know if it is wise to compel the families to return to their Reserve, or allow them to continue fishing until they have caught sufficient fish for the winter. I deemed it advisable to take the latter course.

I also wish to draw the Department's attention to 2 families—John Hardy with 4 children, living at Ozone, and Albert Ray with 3 children, living at Gurney. Both these families have been able to secure work on the Government road, and have built shacks to house their families. Both families have written and reported it would be a great hardship if they were compelled to move back to their Reserve.

If the Department insist on this course I can get in touch with the Mounted Police and see that these families return to their Reservation in order that the children may attend school. As work is so frightfully hard to secure I would suggest that these families remain where they are, and send the children to St. Joseph's Boarding School.

I would be pleased to have the Department's views on the above.

Your obedient servant,

J. G. Bark,
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,

Ottawa, November 18, 1931.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 13th instant, regarding a number of Indian families who have left for their fishing grounds, taking their children with them, and requesting to be informed if steps should be taken by you to have the children placed in school.

In reply I have to say it is considered, in view of the present situation, that it would be more satisfactory for the parents to earn their living than to compel them to return in order that their children can attend school. If, however, you could arrange to have a number of children referred to placed in St. Joseph's Orphanage, Fort William, the Department would be pleased to approve of their admission, provided they are in good health and there is accommodation for them and they would not be in excess of the number for which per capita grant is allowed. It will not be necessary to have the mounted police return these families to their reserve, but if, as stated, you could arrange to have some of these children placed in the residential school at Fort William, the Department will be pleased if you will take the necessary action in this regard.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Dear Mr. Burk—

Ottawa, August 29, 1932.

Sir:

I have to inform you that Miss Leusch, teacher of the Lake Helen Indian Day School, will not resume duties as teacher during the coming academic year, on account of failing health.

The Department is approving of the transfer of Miss Sadie J. Burke, formerly senior teacher of the Wikwemikong Indian Day School, in the Manitowaning agency, to succeed Miss Leusch at Lake Helen. The salary allowed Miss Burke will be at the rate of $100 per teaching month, less 10% for the current fiscal year. I have to request that you will give her any assistance you can in her work and in encouraging a regular attendance of the Indian children. It is understood that Miss Leusch will return to the school as companion and housekeeper for Miss Burke.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,

Ottawa, September 6th, 1934.

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 4th instant, with reference to the Lake Helen Indian Day School.

The Department has been aware for some time that a new teacher was required at this school and, in choosing a teacher, it was understood that the new teacher would take charge of the Lake Helen School. Under these circumstances, the Department is not prepared to transfer Mr. Vesey to Lake Helen. He should resume duties at the Pic School.

In view of the information contained in the last paragraph of your letter, the Department approves the appointment of Miss Doreen Ross, Fort William, Ont., as teacher of the Lake Helen School. She will be allowed salary at the rate of $85 a teaching month. Please let me know the exact date on which this school reopens in order that we may have the information required to include Miss Ross' name on the monthly paylist.

Dear Sir:

In a letter just received from the Department I was told to send in to your office as soon as possible my requisition for irons and ropes for swings and giant's stride. For the swings the following will be needed:

4 bolts with rings attached to fasten to cross-bars.
4 Iron Hooks, half closed to fasten to ends of ropes so that the swings may be taken down during the holidays and in the winter. The hooks are open enough to let rings through.
3 lbs. of 6" nails.

For giant's stride the following is needed:

1 Collar to fit round post, 19" in circumference.
1 Piece of Pipe to be fitted in piece.
8 Rings with one end fastened.
80 feet of Rope.

I am enclosing herewith clipping from catalogue in case the blacksmith has no idea what you wish him to make.

I would be pleased if you would forward this to the Department as soon as possible.

Please send 5 hoes and 3 spades for my garden work. I am just getting the garden plowed up and will plant the seed you sent me very shortly.

Yours respectfully,

(Sgd) E. Leusch.
Port Arthur, Ont.,
June 8th, 1928.

Sir:

Leusch, teacher of the Lake Helen Indian Day School for a swing and Giant's Stride, and in reply I beg to advise I have just received a communication from Miss Leusch, today, requesting me to forward same to the Department,—copy of which is enclosed herewith.

I note the Department is favourably disposed to supply this equipment and would be very pleased to receive the necessary authority.

Your obedient servant,

J. G. Burk,
Indian Agent.

Ottawa, Ontario.

Ottawa, June 13, 1926.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 8th instant, enclosing copy of a communication from Miss E. Leusch, teacher of the Lake Helen Indian Day School, giving a list of the materials required for swings and giant's stride for the playground.

In reply I beg to say that you may arrange for the purchase and delivery of this equipment, and also for the erection of the swings and giant's stride at the school.

You may also purchase 5 hoes and 3 spades for the garden work at this school.

Please keep all expense down as low as possible, and forward accounts, in duplicate, properly certified, in the usual manner covering the expenditure incurred.

Your obedient servant,

Port Arthur, Ont.,
August 24th, 1928.

Sir:

I beg to enclose herewith a list of articles required at the Lake Helen Indian Day School, which has just been received from the teacher, Miss E. Leusch. As many of the articles we purchased for this school are worn out, it will be necessary to replace same with a new supply.

As you will note, Miss Leusch has included a few carpenter tools, which will be used to teach the young Indian children carpenter work. On my last visit to this school I was pleasantly surprised to find that the Indian children take very kindly to carpenter work, but unfortunately the teacher did not have sufficient tools to enable her to carry out this work. I would strongly recommend that her request be granted.

Miss Leusch also inquired if it would be possible to purchase a coal oil stove and oven, and oil cloth for the kitchen floor. The measurements for the latter article will be sent to this office when the teacher returns to the school.

Your obedient servant,

J. G. Burk
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Ottawa, April 26, 1929.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 23rd instant, relative to the request of the teacher of the Lake Helen Indian Day School to be furnished with the supplies asked for in your letter. You may arrange for the purchase and delivery of the following:

- 40 Yds. Rope for Giant's Stride,
- 1 Inexpensive Alarm Clock,
- 4 Hooks and Rings for Swings,
- 3 Drawer Locks,
- 1 Gasoline Lamp.

You may also arrange for the purchase locally, or from a seed man, of the supply of garden seeds required for the school garden.

The Department has noted that the gasoline lamp at present in use is beyond repair and that a new one is required.

After you have made the above purchases, you should forward accounts, in duplicate, in the usual manner covering the expenditure incurred.

Your obedient servant,

Port Arthur, Ont. May 10th 1929

Mr. H. Burke, Esq.

Port Arthur,

Dear Sir:

Don't you think the Indian Department will find it reasonable to increase some of the school house rent at wigwam mission, suppose from $25.00 or a month to $35.00 for the year round? There is a good amount of money invested in this building. Beside the main building, a kitchen has been added a few years ago, which, with some repairs has cost $800.00. This year I have installed a hot water system which have cost about $150.00 and there are always some others repairs to look after. I have also to pay an insurance. But the main part is the depreciation of the property which I calculate to be above $100.00 a year. There is a possibility that this school may close in some years and then the building turns to no use to us and all the money invested is a loss. Will you please submit this to the consideration of the Indian Department.

Sincerely Yours,

T. A. Desautels, F.P.
Reverend.
Sir:

With reference to rental for the Lake Helen Indian Day School, I beg to advise I am enclosing herewith letter from the Rev. T. A. Desaultels, Missionary, which is self-explanatory.

As you will note a new kitchen has been added to the building and a soft water system has been installed costing $150.00. Under the circumstances I would suggest that an increase of $5.00 per month be granted. The Department are now paying $20.00 per month.

An early reply regarding the above will be appreciated.

Your obedient servant,

J. G. Burk,
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Enc.
Ottawa, May 16, 1929.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 13th instant, enclosing a communication from Rev. T. A. Desautels in which he requests an increase in the rental paid for the use of the building for school purposes at Lake Helen. It is noted that an amount has recently been expended in the addition of a new kitchen and the installing of a soft water system.

As you are aware, when the Department first rented this building the sum of $10 per month was paid for its use up to June 30th, 1925. This was increased to $20 per month from that date. Taking into account the locality in which this building is situated, it is thought that the rental now paid is adequate remuneration for the money invested by the missionary in the erection and any repairs made to same. You might, however, make further enquiry and furnish your recommendation as to whether you consider the rental now paid is ample, or if the request of Rev. Father Desautels for an increase be granted.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLEAN

Ottawa, May 21st, 1929.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 18th instant, and in reply have to say that you may arrange for the purchase and delivery of the following supplies for the use of the Lake Helen Indian Day School: 2 cocoa mats, inexpensive; 3 locks, with keys, for school cupboards, and 1 refill for fire extinguisher. You should see that no unnecessary expense is incurred, and when the refill for the fire extinguisher is delivered, you should arrange to have it placed in the extinguisher and see that the extinguisher is put in good condition and ready for use in case of fire.

Relative to the request of the teacher that the walls and ceiling of the classroom be cleaned, I have to say that, while you have not stated the approximate cost of this work, the Department will approve of your arranging to have it carried out. You may purchase the material required. It is thought that if these walls were kalsomined it would be satisfactory. It is expected that you will keep all expense in the cleaning of the walls of the classroom as low as possible.

Please forward accounts, in duplicate, properly certified covering the above authorized expenditure.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

I beg to report I have just received a communication from Dr. A. Quackenbush of Nipigon, Ontario. He reports after carefully examining the children of the Lake Helen Indian Day School that 8 pupils have contracted tuberculosis. He strongly recommends that the following supplies be purchased for these children in order to build them up:

1 Case of Tomatoes,
2 lbs. Carrots,
4 Heads of Cabbage,
10 lbs. Spanish Onions,
10 lbs. Butter,
10 doz. Eggs,
1 box Apples,
Separate Drinking Cups.

The doctor also advised purchasing an inexpensive set of scales.

Miss Leusch, teacher of this school, just communicated with this office advising she would be very willing to do everything in her power to cope with the situation and will, if the Department purchases the supplies, give the children 2 nourishing meals daily.

I would strongly recommend that the above provisions be purchased as soon as possible.

An early reply will be appreciated.

Your obedient servant,

J. G. Burk,
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Ottawa, January 17, 1930.

Sir,

In view of the report contained in your letter of the 8th instant regarding children of the Lake Helen Indian Day School who have contracted tuberculosis, I beg to say the Department approves of purchase being made, as recommended by Dr. Quackenbush, of the supplies which you have enumerated in order that two nourishing meals may be provided daily on behalf of the said children, which work Miss Leusch, the teacher, has signified willingness to do.

An inexpensive set of scales may be purchased as recommended.

Form No. 101
Sir:

I beg to report I have just received a letter from Miss E. Leusch, teacher of the Lake Helen Day School. Miss Leusch reports she has been in the habit of using a borrowed wheelbarrow to convey supplies from the station to the school, a distance of 2 miles. The wheelbarrow is very dilapidated and cannot be used. Under the circumstances I would recommend that one be purchased for the school.

The teacher also reports she requires some inexpensive curtains and blinds.

I would be pleased to receive the necessary authority to purchase the above supplies as soon as possible, as the school will reopen again on September 2nd.

Your obedient servant,

J. G. Burk,
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.
Ottawa, August 27th, 1930.

Sir,

I have your letter of the 21st instant, relative to the request of the teacher of the Lake Helen Indian Day School to be supplied with a wheelbarrow. In this connection, I have to say that you may arrange for the purchase and delivery of a suitable wheelbarrow. You may, also, purchase and have delivered the blinds and curtain material required, no unnecessary expense to be incurred.

I have, also, the list of table equipment which the teacher requires. In this connection, I have to say that you may arrange for the purchase and delivery of the various articles as mentioned in the list, which is returned herewith. After the above purchases have been made, you should forward accounts in duplicate, properly certified, covering the cost.

In connection with vouchers covering supplies purchased for this school, I have to request that, in future, you will state definitely on each voucher whether the supplies are strictly for the use of the school or are in payment for food, etc., supplied for the tubercular children, as this expenditure is paid from a separate vote than that of supplies which are strictly for the use of the school.

Your obedient servant,

T. R. L. MacInnes
For Secretary.

J. G. Burk, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Port Arthur, Ont.

Form No. 101
Sir:

I beg to draw the attention of the Department to a request from Miss Leusch, teacher of the Lake Helen Indian Day School, who recently called at this office. Miss Leusch reports it would be a great help to the Indian children if the Department would purchase an inexpensive cobbler set, which would help the pupils and their parents to be thrifty, and also repair their own boots.

The cost of the set, including the leather would be $3.50.

As I anticipate the hunting season will be extremely poor this year, which will render the Indians very destitute, I would strongly recommend purchasing this set.

An early reply will be appreciated.

Your obedient servant,

J. G. Burk,
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.
Ottawa, September 16th, 1930.

Sir,

I have your letter of the 13th instant, relative to the request of the teacher of the Lake Helen Indian Day School to be supplied with an inexpensive cobbler set for the use of the pupils and their parents in repairing their boots.

In this connection, I have to say that you may arrange for the purchase and delivery of the set, including leather, at a cost estimated by you to be $3.50. After this outfit has been supplied, you should furnish an account in duplicate, properly certified, covering the cost.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Indian Agent,

Ottawa, December 9, 1930.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 4th instant, requesting that a grant be provided to purchase gifts for the pupils of the Indian day schools in your Agency, and enclosing a list of articles for the Christmas tree at the Lake Helen Indian Day School.

In reply I have to say that the Department will approve of an expenditure being incurred not exceeding the following amount for each of the schools:

- Lake Helen ............ $15.00
- Mission Bay .......... 10.00
- Mobert ................ 7.00
- Pic ................... 10.00
- Sand Point ............ 7.00
- Gull Bay .............. 12.00
- Whitesand ............. 5.00

Please obtain itemized accounts covering the expenditure incurred for each school separately. These you should attach to proper voucher forms, certify in the usual manner and send to the Department for payment.

The list which you enclosed from the teacher of the Lake Helen School is returned herewith. Either the teacher or yourself should arrange for the purchase of the articles requested.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Indian Agent,

Ottawa, June 8th, 1931.

Sir,

In a report regarding his visit to the Lake Helen Indian Day School on April 17th, last, Inspector Greening states that he found some of the boys busily cutting pieces of tin out of the sides of old oil cans for use as shingles as the roof was beginning to leak.

As the Department pays a very fair rental for the use of this building, it is felt that it should be kept in a habitable condition. You should, therefore, arrange to have Father Desautel make any repairs required to the roof. It is understood, of course, that such repairs will be made without expense to this Department, as we only pay rent for the building and are not liable for repairs such as these.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,

Sir:

I beg to enclose herewith letter from Miss S. J. Burke, teacher of the Lake Helen Indian Day School which is self-explanatory.

For the Department's information Dr. Quackenbush at Nipigon made a thorough examination of the school children last year and found that the majority of them were tubercular. As you will note there are 6 active tubercular cases attending school who should receive nourishing food. Miss Leusch, who was teaching at the school last year, and is now acting as housekeeper was in the habit of giving the children an egg-nog, which is very nourishing. Miss Burke, as you will note, by the enclosed list has suggested the following monthly rations: 15 doz. Eggs, 1 case of Milk, 30 lbs. Carrots, and 5 lbs. Sugar.

Additional rations for other tubercular children at the school as follows: 5 lbs. Butter, 10 lbs. Sugar, 10 lbs. Carrots, 3 doz. Eggs.

The teacher has also sent a requisition for: 6 lengths of stove pipes, 2 elbows, and 1 roll of stove pipe wire.

A barrel of coal oil weighs 450 lbs. and it is impossible to get these barrels in canoes and have them conveyed to the Reserves. Consequently it is necessary to purchase in 4 gallon tins. I may say that the Hudson's Bay Company purchases all their coal oil in 4 gallon tins, as it is impossible to handle the barrels.

The schools are some distance from the station and the oil has to be conveyed by canoes and boats to the Reserve. It is, therefore necessary to purchase the oil in 4 gallon tins, and $1.00 is charged for each tin, consequently the price is much higher than in barrel lots.

Your obedient servant,

J. G. Burk,
Indian Agent.

Reverend Father LaBelle visited this office today and discussed the situation at Lake Helen. Re: Repairs - Lake Helen Indian Day School

Pursuant to past correspondence on the above subject, we have obtained from Father O. Labelle, a statement in the form of an account of the repair work he has undertaken.

Apparently you vetoed the idea of vouchering the school rental at $40. per month rather than $20. per month, as a method of repaying Father Labelle. Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources, Ottawa, Ont.

Proposed New Day School, Lake Helen.

With reference to your wire of Nov. 26th, which read as follows: "RE LAKE HELEN SCHOOL UNDERSTAND TENDERS FORTHCOMING STOP ADVISE SOONEST AS INTEND TRANSFER FUNDS OTHER PROJECTS", I am enclosing two bids for this proposed school. One is from Mr. O. Vezina, Fort Arthur, in the amount of $19,537.00 and the other is from Mr. Jos. Skopyk, Fort William, amounting to $17,409.00. The latter contractor was the builder of the recently completed Mountain Village I.D.S., on the Fort William Reserve, which was inspected by Mr. A.J. Doucet of your Branch.

At the present time, Mr. Skopyk is completing a new R.C. Church at Nipigon and our proposed I.D.S. would be located only a short distance from this church, and he informs me he could start construction at once on the school, with 19 men available, including four treaty Indians.

I did not forward bids at an earlier date, for I was waiting word from you in connection with the Arroland School. As a new school is badly needed to serve the Nipigon Indians, I trust that authorization can be given to start construction immediately.

As electricity is just a short distance from the location of the proposed school, I hope authorization to wire the school can be obtained. I also hope that suitable plumbing, (similar to that installed in the Mountain Village School), can be installed, including septic tank, a bath, hand basin and a kitchen sink. As our skilled Indian tradesmen in the Agency are all pretty well tied up with regular employment, which they do not want to jeopardize, we cannot count on their employment on this project, but as stated the contractor can place the required workers on the job at once, when authorized.

J.G. Burk, Indian Sup't.

Memorandum:

MR. ALLAN,

This will confirm our telephone conversation of yesterday's date. I had a long distance phone conversation with Mr. Indian Superintendent Burk, of the Port Arthur Agency. He advised me that he would forward to you a proposal for the purchase of some thirty acres as a reserve for the Indians living at Lake Helen.

He advised me that these Indians have not been living on a reserve for a good many years but have been living near the Jesuit Mission at Lake Helen. Apparently, their reserve is somewhat isolated and the land on which they are now living is much more suitable from their point of view.

As you are probably aware, I cannot have a new school built for these Indians unless it is situated on an Indian reserve. I understand that Mr. Burk has received an offer from a Mr. Don Clark for the sale to the Branch of one acre of land for the sum of One Dollar. Apparently Mr. Clark is anxious to help these Indians and wishes to make this land available for school purposes for these Indian children.

Bernard E. Neary,
Superintendent of Education.

ATTENTION: Col. B. F. Neary, Superintendent of Education.

With reference to previous correspondence, and also our telephone conversation last week regarding the building of an Indian Day School at Lake Helen Mission, the situation at this point is rather a difficult one. The Reserve proper is situated at the mouth of the Nipigon River, a distance of approximately 4½ miles from the Mission. The largest percentage of the Indians had lived at the Mission for many years, owing to the fact that the school and church were situated there. Unfortunately the condition of the school for years was deplorable, also the teacher Mr. Veysey was most inefficient. These facts caused many of the Indian families to move to scattered locations around the town of Nipigon, which is approximately one mile from the Mission. The Missionary and myself feel that if a new school were built at the Mission, many of these families would move back.

On my last visit to the Lake Helen School, there were twenty-six pupils, eighteen of which were Treaty Indians. The remainder were non-Treaty and white children. We are attaching a list of the pupils at the school.

In my conversation I stated the property where the school would be built belonged to Mr. D. A. Clark. However I find that after going over the property with the surveyor, it is owned by the Jesuit Missionaries and not by Mr. Clark. Father Labelle has informed me that they will transfer sufficient property for school and grounds to our Department.
May I also point out that the Municipality of Nipigon is willing to transfer to our Department, twenty-five acres of park property previously transferred to the Department of Highways, who have abandoned plans for using this property. This location is a few hundred feet from the new school site. Needless to say the Municipality is anxious to see the Indians move from town property back to the Mission.

I am enclosing a map showing proposed school location and park property, also a copy of a letter addressed to Mr. Allan, which is self-explanatory.

J. G. Burk,
Indian Superintendent.

MEMORANDUM

Mr. B. F. Neely,
Superintendent of Education.

Referring to your memoranda of December 7th and 17th, this Division is awaiting Mr. Burk's letter and plan referred to in his letter to you of December 9th, file 402-5.

The Indians at the Lake Helen Mission appear to be a part of the Red Rock Band which numbers 223 according to the census. A substantial number, apparently about twenty families, live either at the Mission at Lake Helen or at Nipigon. They appear to wish to remain at Lake Helen Mission rather than move to their Reserve at Red Rock.

It further appears that the local white community at Nipigon want these Indians to live at the Lake Helen Mission rather than in the vicinity of the town of Nipigon and the Municipality offers us 25 acres of municipally owned land for their accommodation. It also appears that the Jesuit Mission is prepared to make available to us a site from the Mission property on which to build a school.

If the 25-acre block offered by the Municipality would serve as the site of an Indian village (with gardens, etc.), it might be desirable to secure it and constitute it an Indian Reserve as an addition to their present Reserve No. 53 at Red Rock (468 acres).

This appears to the writer to be feasible if the site is suitable and the permanent establishment of this group at Lake Helen is approved.
It is suggested that the first requirement would be a legal survey of the parcels to be acquired and the second step would be to have it duly constituted an Indian Reserve by Order in Council as an addition to Red Rock No. 53.

From the number of Indian school children in the group as reported by Superintendent Burk, I would estimate that there might be twenty families to accommodate at this point.

D. J. Allan,
Superintendent,
