Re: Lake Helen School

On May 27th accompanied by Mr. Burk of Port Arthur and Mr. MacCrimmon of Ottawa, I went over the locality of the above proposed school.

First of all there are at the present time only twelve Indian children of school age in the vicinity of the proposed school. This number will be increased if we secure title to and establish a reserve on the twenty-five acres bounding the river. Without this increase it seems hardly necessary to build a school.

The children could be sent by bus to Nipigon and receive a good education among white children for a much lower cost. Mr. Greening, the school inspector, thought this would be to the best advantage of the children.

I would not recommend either of the other sites of one acre or so suggested by Mr. Burk. The School should be the centre of the community. To place it at the end of the settlement would reduce its value.

Mr. Burk was requested to trace the matter of the land transfer of twenty-five acres. When this is complete we can then start to develop the reserve. The date of June 10th was set as a deadline, if the title is not assured by then it can be assumed no school will be built this year and the money transferred to some other school.
The present building is hardly fit to use next year. In the event a new school is not built this year, and this does not appear likely to be done, I would recommend that transportation be arranged to take the Indian children, about twelve in number, to Nipigon.

F. Matters,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies.

LAKE HELEN INDIAN DAY SCHOOL INSPECTION REPORT

Date of Inspection - September 23, 1949.

School Building
This is not a Government owned school but is operated in the building rented from the Church. It is a poor building and will obviously have to be replaced when the problem of the establishment of a new reserve is settled.

Teacher and classroom
Miss M. Cox has a second class certificate from Quebec Province and has eight years of experience in Indian schools and seven years of experience in provincial schools. She is not a good teacher and has not recently attended summer school. She is a teacher of the type we are trying to replace in our schools. She has made no effort to improve her professional standing in spite of repeated warnings from the Department. I do not consider we should retain her services in anything but a small school where the services of any other teachers are not available. She should most definitely not be hired for the new school when it is erected.

Achievement Tests
There were 23 children enrolled with 14 Indians and 9 non-Indians. These were in Grades 1-6. These children tested poorly. Their reading was unsatisfactory and she did not have the teachers' manuals nor had she ever used them. In fact she was using the wrong readers in Grade II. There was little evidence that she was attempting to follow the course of study.

Recommendations:
1. The new school should be erected when the matter

.....2
of the reserve is settled.

2. The site has already been selected by Mr. Matters, Mr. Burk and myself.

3. It should be possible to erect a school with electricity and running water.

4. Miss Cox should be employed in a newly opened school where Indian children are very primitive and require only basic education.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Ottawa, July 22nd, 1914

Sir,

Referring to the personal report made by you while in Ottawa last week that there were about twenty children of school age on the Lower French River Reserve for whom education facilities should be provided, I beg to say that the Department would like to know whether a building could be obtained in which a school could be maintained there and if so, on what terms.

I beg to report to you that I was at Pickerel Lower French River Reserve, on Friday 24th, and made inquiries re children of school age, and as to building a school house.

There are at the present time 13 Indian children between 6 and 14 years of age, and quite a few under 6, also some 10 or 12 white children at the mill.

Mr. Bruce of the Pickerel river Lumber Co. says they will help and might supply the lumber for the building, if the Department will do the rest, but he will take it up with his partner, Mr. Plannt of Ottawa, and let me know.

I think the Department might call up Mr. Plannt and have a talk with him.

The mill site is one mile from Pickerel Station and is on the Reserve. That would be a good place for the school and about central for the Indians, who live across the river, about one or two miles away.

I was talking to the Indians about it and they are jubilant at the prospect of having a school in their midst.

Trusting this may have your favor and an early reply,

I am Your Obedient Servant,

Indian Supt.

Sir,

In connection with previous correspondence relative to the Indians living at Pickerel River I beg to say that some of the Indians of this band, who have been to see the Department, state that they are still anxious to have a school there and would be willing to put up a building to be paid for out of their per capita funds.

The Indians state that the mill owners are willing to contribute lumber to the extent of one-quarter of the cost of the material and the Indians themselves would be capable of putting up the building by day labour.

This matter should be attended to this winter, so that the work, if undertaken, could commence early in the spring.

Your obedient servant,

Ottawa, 16th April, 1920.

Sir,

On behalf of the Contin island band of Indians residing at Pickerel I beg to submit to the consideration of the Department the advisability of opening a school amongst them.

These Indians never had a school, and such state of things should be discontinued. A school should be established at Pickerel on the main land where there are over 12 Indian children of school age and about that number on the Contin island. The Indians are making their homes in the village of Pickerel where they secure ready and steady employment in the mill of the Pine Lake Lumber Co. The children of the white people of the village would also attend school and I am sure they would bear part of the expense of the establishment and maintenance of such a school. For further details in the scheme, reference could be made to Supt. Logan who is acquainted with the needs of these people in this matter.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

I beg to submit to you Minutes of Council meeting held at Pickreil, Henry Inlet on May 3rd at which I was present. After voting on two surrenders for lease of land to Pine Lake Lumber Co and to James Ludgate for a Mill site the following business was discussed and motions passed.

The question of erecting a school at Pickreil was discussed and it was moved by John Wikemakis and seconded by Wm Missabie that the school be built on the mill side of the river instead of on the island. Carried.

Parry Sound,
May 11 1920.

I beg to submit to you minutes of meeting held at Pickreil on May 3rd, at which I had a good attendance of Indians as I paid out Interest money. It is very hard to have a good meeting there unless it is payday as the Indians are scattered over a large area. I endeavoured to have a meeting before to submit the Surrender but could never get enough of them together, however we had a good meeting on the 3rd and took up a lot of important business.

The question of a school was gone into and as I explained to the Indians there was no use doing anything until they decided and agreed on a site as a great many wanted it built on the Island where only a few Indian children lived and where it would be impossible to get a teacher to live. If they agreed to have it on the mill side of the river, the Pine Lake people would help them and suggested a union school and I have a promise from Mr Fraser of the Pine Lake Co. that they will build the building and supply the fuel to heat it if the Indian Dep't will run it or any other arrangements satisfactory to the Indian Department as they must have a school there being a great many white children.

I would like to know if the Dept would be in favour of a union school or purely Indian school. I think there would be about 22 children belonging to the band who could attend a Logan. [Handwritten]

MEMORANDUM.

Mr. Scott,

Mr. Superintendent Logan forwards a resolution, of a meeting of Council held at Pickerel, requesting that a school be established for the use of the Indian and white children residing on Contin Island Reserve and on the mainland in the village of Pickerel. The school is for the benefit of the children of the Indian and white employees of the Pine Lake Lumber Company. A number of the Indians live on Contin Island, but the majority reside near the plant of the lumber company.

Superintendent Logan states that there are about 22 children belonging to the band who would attend, besides there are a number of white children for whom no educational facilities are provided. He states that the Pine Lake Lumber Company suggests a union school and that they will put up a building on their property and supply the fuel, if the Department will provide the equipment and pay the salary of a teacher. The Indians at this point secure steady employment in the lumber mills. A request was made in 1914 for the establishment of a combined school at this point.

Recently I had a visit from Mr. Cole, a member of the Pine Lake Lumber Company. He requested that a combined school for the Indian and white children be established. He stated that the white people would be prepared to bear their share of the expense.

As the Indian children at this point are receiving no education, I think that a good arrangement to provide the same would be to combine with the white people, and, if the lumber company will erect a building and supply the fuel, we should furnish the equipment such as desks, school material and
and blackboards, and engage the teacher and pay the salary. This school, if erected in the village of Pickerel, would be on what was formerly the lower French River Reserve, but the portion on which the village is situated was surrendered to the C. P. R. for piling grounds and has since by them been transferred to the lumber company. By combining with the white employees of the lumber company the Department would obtain educational facilities for the Indian children at much less expense than if a school were erected and carried on for the benefit of the Indian children only.

I would suggest that Mr. Superintendent Logan be instructed to communicate with the Pine Lake Lumber Company with a view to having them provide a suitable building, and, if the building is provided by them, that this Department engage a teacher and pay the salary.
Ottawa, June 9, 1920.

You should take this matter up with the company as soon as possible and inform the Department as to whether they will comply with the Department's offer for the carrying on of a union school for the Indian and white children in the village of Pickeral.

At a meeting held at Pickeril, Heny Inlet Reserve, it was resolved that a school house be erected on Countin Island for the benefit of the Indian children of which there are at present some eighteen.

Mr. Fraser of the Pine lake Lumber Co. will supply all the rough material for a building 20x30, if the Department will pay for labor and other supplies.

OTTAWA, July 22nd, 1921.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 19th instant with reference to the erection of a school building on Countin Island for the benefit of the Indian children.

In reply, I beg to say that the Department is not disposed to pay for the cost of the work of putting up a building, furnishing the same and for its future maintenance for the benefit of Indian children only. It is considered that the arrangements made last year for the erection of a joint school for white and Indian children residing in the village of Pickerel and on Countin Island should be adhered to, as per official letter to you of June 9th, 1920. It is doubtful if a school for the benefit of Indian children only would meet with the success which would warrant the Department in assuming the cost of the work of putting up the building, and for maintenance and payment of the teacher's salary.

In letter to you of June 9th, 1920, mentioned above, you were requested to take up with the management of the Pine Lake Lumber Company the erection by them of a building of suitable size to accommodate the Indian and white children, also that they agree to supply the fuel required, engage the services of a properly qualified teacher and assume a proportionate share of the cost of salary.

You should inform the Indians at Pickerel accordingly, and endeavour to have them consent to the establishment of a joint school, and you should also arrange with the Lumber Company for the carrying out of the arrangement as mentioned above.

Your obedient servant,

A. Logan, Esq.,
Indian Superintendent,
Parry Sound, Ont.

Sir:

I have your No. 8-229 of the 21st ultimo, referring to the educational needs of the Lower French River Reserve, Henvey Inlet.

In reply I wish to review, for your information, the facts on file and ask for your recommendation. During the past year this Indian band at Pickerel surrendered about one-half an acre to a Public School Board for a school site. The original intention was to operate a combined white and Indian school. The school Board and the Ontario Department of Education decided on a public school for white children only, and in the lease of the school site we asked for an annual rental of $25.00.

The former Indian Agent, Mr. A. Logan, informed the Department in January of this year that the Indian band at Pickerel were somewhat disappointed over the attitude taken by the white people. Our representative intimated that the Indian band would like a school of their own at Countin Island. It was reported at that time that there were 6 families on the island with 14 children of school age and 3 families on the mainland near the Pine Lake Company's mill with 5 children of school age, making a total of 19 Indian children who could be accommodated at a day school on the island.

Mr. Logan reported also that there was a good building 20 x 30 on the island, which was used for church services and could be bought for, roughly, $100. It would require some alterations and improvements amounting to about $200 to put it in good condition. He believed that the Pine Lake Lumber Company would give some assistance and that the teacher could live at the company's boarding house.

Would you either visit Pickerel or make enquiries regarding this church building and ascertain if it can be purchased, and the amount necessary in the event of a transfer. Also offer the Department a rough estimate as to the cost of putting it in shape for school purposes. The Pine Lake Lumber Company might be approached with a view to securing the necessary lumber for the alterations, gratis, and to learning if a teacher could be accommodated at their boarding house. Please state whether it is possible to cross from the mainland to the island at all seasons of the year, and make a general recommendation as to the advisability of commencing a day school for the Pickerel band. In the earlier correspondence this proposed school has been spoken of as the Lower French River Indian Day School.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

At Pickerel Reserve, a young teacher, Miss Mary Casper from Pembroke, is doing fine, but she is in love with a boy who goes in her house too often and too late at night. She gives lots of trouble, people saying that the fellow sleeps in there, but I don't believe that he sleeps in there, but I know, because I saw, that the fellow goes there often, and leaves around midnight. Notice that the girl is always living alone, so last February I tried to stop the boy from going so often (the boy is an operator without work) and the girl and the boy, after a big scrape, fired me out.

So I would like her to change her school because it is impossible to persuade her to quit those frequent visits. She will do fine in some other school, and really I am sorry to write about her dismissal, and it took me two years before doing it, for the girl has certainly great qualities, but love spoiled everything, and a two years courtship is enough, on a reserve, without any danger.

If it is possible, don't mention my name in your dealing with Miss Casper, please.

Father Porcheron and we had a conversation; he verified some of the rumours that were going around. On questioning him, he reluctantly told me that he has spoken to you about the situation.

After considering the matter carefully, I have come to the conclusion that it would be for your good to resign the position as teacher in the Lower French Indian Day School. If you send in your resignation, I will feel that I am in a position to give you a splendid reference for your services while with me. I am very sorry to write you in this strain, but feel it is the kindest thing to do, to ask you to resign. The teachers in my Agency are expected to be very careful not to be a party to any rumours that would be detrimental to the school or the Reserve. As stated before, I don't believe all the rumours that I hear, and I shall be pleased, if you send in your resignation, to recommend you for your three years faithful service. Trusting you will understand my position and be advised by me.

Sir;

Yours of June 16th, 22-6-1, re conversation between Rev. Porcheron and myself concerning Miss Casper, the teacher at Lower French Indian Day School. In my conversation with Rev. Porcheron, I stated to him that being the father of five girls most of them grown to womanhood, I felt a great responsibility concerning the lady teachers in my Agency and asked Rev. Porcheron, if he as a Missionary Priest had cause to speak to Miss Casper about a young man, who has been paying her court, for staying late at night at the teacher's house, Lower French Reserve.

Father Porcheron, said he had. I explained to him my desire at all times to cooperate with the church for the betterment of the Indian, particularly in connection with scholastic matters. He was delighted at my remarks (which I thought rather strange) for this reason. He, Rev. Porcheron seemed to rather welcome my statement that although I had sympathy with young men and maidens in their love affairs I did not believe all I was told about Miss Casper and her young man keeping unseemly hours but the dignity of the Department of Indian Affairs must be upheld and that the Department could not afford to have even a breath of suspicion cast upon their teaching staff, and as there was a talk among the whites and Indians that the young man who is paying court to Miss Casper was staying late at the teacher's house, and as Miss Casper had made application to continue teaching I was going to write him, as I had heard he had found it necessary to speak to Miss Casper about the matter. I said I was glad I had met him, and went into all the details of what he knew, and I found out by his conversation that he knew nothing except that there were suspicions.
that there might be improper conduct between Miss Casper and her intended.

I asked him to keep me posted on any teachers whom he thought might be suitable and he said he would, and immediately mentioned two teachers, one of whom the Department refused to have teach in this Agency. I then told him not to do anything definite, as from experience I knew he is inclined to reach beyond his depth, in matters which he has nothing to do with. I told him I would write to Miss Casper in a fatherly way, advising her to resign, as I did not mean to be the cause of any harm to this young woman, whom I know to have wonderful qualities as a young woman and as a teacher.

Enclosed is a copy of the letter I mailed to Miss Casper on the following day, to which I have not received a reply, yet.

Sir, when I was talking to the Rev. Porcheron about Miss Casper, it was in strict confidence, because Miss Casper lost her father in the Halifax disaster and her mother worked to put her through Normal, therefore I did not want her to be dismissed without just cause and for that reason, I sent her the enclosed letter asking her to resign. The letter will explain itself. I was trying to play cricket or ball, as I understand it should be played. I explained in confidence about some trouble I had with a teacher and how I booted the young man out of the house, and warned him if he was seen on the Reserve again I would have him arrested. I then told the teacher she was through. I also explained how the Department had insisted I must get proof of misconduct, and explained to him that I furnished the proof to the satisfaction of the Department, but I hated myself for having been forced to do so, as I expected the Department would have accepted my word that it was time for a change. I did not say to him that it was suggested to me after I took over the Agency at Parry Sound that the teacher referred to was of an obliging disposition.

The reason for this lengthy letter to the Department in the case of Miss Casper, and the enclosed letter from me to Miss Casper asking her to resign, is this; I do not want to be a party that would injure the prospects of Miss Casper earning her living. My letter to Miss Casper explains my position in the case and I would like to be able to recommend her for her services in this
Agency, and I feel that I can honestly do so, therefore I feel I do not approve of the Rev. Porcheron writing the Department on the matter at all. I do not think he was playing good cricket, I do not think he was playing cricket at all. Furthermore, my belief in the Service as I understand the Service, is this; that the Church and the state can cooperate for the general good of the people but when the Church starts to take upon itself the duties of the officials of the state, in my opinion it is time the service as representing the state should tell the Church in a diplomatic manner to hustle, hustle, and play ball, play cricket as it should be played.

Enclosed also is petition from the members of the Lower French Band, brought to this office by Miss Casper.

Trusting the Department will understand my situation as their representative in the field in Parry Sound and Muskoka Districts.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Agent.

Enclosed you will find a letter from the Indian Agent Mr. Daly, also my reply to same.

In connection with my resignation and the receiving of this letter I deemed it advisable to write the Dept. for some information.

On June 16th, Mr. Daly advised me to resign. A few days previous to this he was in Pickerel and in the presence of a number of Indians stated that I would have my school another year. I explained the cause of the trouble to Mr. Daly and he said he would in turn explain same to the Dept. If this has not been done I would be very glad to furnish further information. I delayed resigning for two weeks because the Indians who still want me back urged me to do so. They sent a petition to Mr. Daly to have me remain and a councillor went personally but he deemed it advisable to refuse this.

On June 29th, I got a 2nd notice from the Agent and it stated that if I did not resign he would be forced to "act differently" I did so immediately and stated that I would leave as soon as possible. On July 6th, I received the enclosed letter.

For my own information I would like to know is a teacher given a months notice as in other schools. After fixing and doing what I have for this school I cannot understand matters if it is the Departments wishes that a teacher should have the shortest notice possible instead of a month as is customary. Dear Mr. Sutherland,

I have been away all summer on important business in the U.S.A. and just got back this morning to find that my house here had been broken into at different times during the summer and several things taken.

I have not yet gone over things thoroughly to make a complete inventory but the intruders were evidently surprised on their last entrance because they left quite a load of canned goods in a heap in the back porch, having entered by the front and gone out by the back.

The house keys had been left with two reliable persons, Frank Kelton.
and Paul Joseph and they have visited the house from time to time to keep tabs on it. They discovered this last affair last Sunday and left everything as they found it as they were at a loss what to do until they would hear from me.

The thieves stole a flour tin and quite a lot of food stuffs. The flour tin was the property of the government, goes with the house—they also stole a considerable amount of coal oil. Left the canned goods untouched on account of finger prints as this habit could become a serious matter. Bureau drawers and trunks were rummaged and things in general left in a most disorderly mess.

I spoke to Mr. Daly some time ago about the first Yale lock having been
transferred with but he did nothing about it. I have been in the habit of locking the front door this way, the back door lock has a very ordinary lock, the key of which was thrown away when the intruders beat a hasty retreat through the back door, having entered by the front—it was impossible to get in but the back door the second time as the boys had raised it and bolted the inside back door.

I have notified the Police of this and would appreciate your cooperation in whatever is advisable to prevent a recurrence of this rather serious deed.

I trust you have had a pleasant summer. How about my June requisition?

Sincerely,

Dear Sir,

Referring to conversation with you some little time ago, I now wish to tender my resignation from the position of teacher of the Lower Severn River Indian Day School on the Lower Severn Reserve, & takes effect at the end of the December quarter.

From all appearances we are to have an early winter so that I am looking forward to being able to remove my piano and other furniture as soon as there is good ice on the river.

As outlined in part by you when we met, I have other very interesting work awaiting me in Sudbury and I am anxious to go albeit the fact that in many ways it grieves me to leave my
I like my children and they like me but a nice ready-made family for my own little lovable son appeals to me very strongly. If you remember, I appreciated you with some of the facts regarding my personal life and I am happy to be able to say that the plans for the future appear to be almost entirely satisfactory and successful.

In view of my experience here and the work which I have done amongst the people, I wonder if I may be allowed to make a suggestion for the Dept. of Education. Please that they will not send any poor little misguided, inexperienced teacher to this very lovely place. It is wonderful country here, if you are fitted to this life and are not dependent on any social life whatsoever. Also, if possible (and it ought to) send one with some experience in nursing; this is very isolated and you will find, by looking up the records of the Medical end of the Reserve...
that the medical expenses were much lower,
and the sickness very much less while I was
on the Reserve. All the Reserves needed more than
just a teacher. I have done a very thorough
nursing service here, always ready and willing
when they called, which has been at all hours, and
I have travelled considerably over land and water
the Indians. The Doctor's visits have been very few.

In view of these facts, and the added fact
that I have been obliged to ferry the children
very frequently, for a month at a time last year and
this — always at my own expense, would it be
too much of the Department that they pass approval
on the attached bills and forward check to cover. The
three fifteen ($3.15) is for general repairs, greasing etc.,
to engine after being in use two and a half years.

You see, I also have had and will have
again, considerable expenses in transferring
my piano and other articles from the island.
These have greatly facilitated my life here and
made a pleasant social and musical life for the
Indians so I would appreciate a little help.
on these accounts.

May I add here that my association with the Department have been most pleasant; the kindness and consideration shown at all times have been very gratifying and I surely appreciate it.

The day that Miss Biasucci was appointed to this School, Miss O'Toole was at my office and was very much perturbed because she did not get the opportunity. She is desirous of being near her people.

I promised her that if there should happen to be a vacancy at the Lower French School, where she taught before, that I would put her name forward. This I am doing now. Miss O'Toole was quite a success in this school. She said she would take the school if she received the same salary that she is getting at Christian Island. I think she should get the same salary as she gets in Christian Island as she has the knack of making the children attend school.
I would therefore recommend that Miss O'Toole be transferred from Christian Island School, back to her old school at Lower French.

Please reply by return mail if possible, as I expect to be up at her home in Britt next week.

Your very earnest consideration in this matter will be very much appreciated, as I do not like to break my word to either the Indians or the teachers.

Ottawa, July 26th, 1928.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 23rd instant, enclosing applications which you received for the position as teacher at the Lower French River Indian Day School.

It is noted that you recommend the appointment of Miss Mary Casper, who was also recommended by the Principal of the North Bay Normal School. The Department will approve of her appointment. If she cannot accept, you may offer the position to Miss Margaret Berrigan. As stated in our letter of June 22nd, last, the salary allowed will be at the rate of $85 per teaching month. It is to be understood that the teacher appointed is a Roman Catholic. Please communicate with Miss Casper, and ascertain definitely whether she will accept and if she will be ready to begin duties when the school re-opens after the present summer holidays, on or about September 4th, next, and you should inform the Department accordingly. In the event of her not accepting, you may offer the position to Miss Berrigan.

The applications which you forwarded are returned as requested, and when you are communicating with the department, giving the name of the teacher whom you have secured, you should return the original application of the teacher appointed for record on our file.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Aast. Deputy and Secretary.

John M. Daly, Esq.,
Indian Agent,

Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 17th instant, reporting on your visit to Contain Island with regard to the question of providing school facilities for the children who reside at that point.

In reply I beg to say that the Department approves of the purchase of the log building on the island—particulars of which you have mentioned in your letter—and will pay the owner thereof the sum of $70.00.

It will also be necessary to procure approximately an acre of land surrounding the building, to provide play etc. It is hoped that the owner of the building will dispose of his interest in that quantity of land. If so, will be necessary to obtain a quit claim deed, signed by the owner of the building and land, and in that case it is desired a proper description of the same to be included in the deed. If an acre of ground is obtained it should be, if possible, square, which will comprise approximately one acre.

Enclosed is a blue print of the Indian Reserve good enough to mark on it the location of the building and school site, and draw out on a separate sheet of paper, larger scale, a plan showing the boundaries of the lot length in feet of each of the sides; also mark on this north point. This information will be sufficient to enable us to make a definite description of the site and plot it on our plan. When forwarding these particulars, you will enclose a voucher in duplicate covering the amount to be paid to the Indian for the building and site; this voucher should bear the name of the Indian owner.

We note your estimate of the approximate cost of $200—to fit up the building for school purpose. We will agree to the granting of the land required, subject to having the repairs as enumerated in your letter carried out. A brick chimney should be built, the roof covered with shingles, a new floor laid, the chinks between the logs plastered, the building whitewashed inside and out and any other work in the windows. In the purchase of any material for this purpose, you will please obtain competitive prices for the goods from the firm quoting the lowest price. The work can be employed and proper time sheets in full kept, showing the number of days the individual was employed.

When the repairs have been completed, we will supply the necessary desks, blackboards and other school equipment. We shall endeavour to secure the services of a teacher, and the teacher could arrange to live at the house.

Indian Agent,

Sir:

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 15th instant, requisitioning for desks, blackboards, etc., required for the use of the new school on Contint Island, Lower French River Reserve.

In reply I beg to say that we are calling for prices from a number of manufacturers for the supplying of the following school desks:

- 10 Single desks for pupils 7-10 yrs.,
- 8 " " " " 9-14 yrs.,
- 6 " " " " 12-16 yrs.

This will provide seating accommodation for 24 children. We are also obtaining prices for the supplying of a teacher's desk and chair.

The blackboard, maps, etc., will be ordered from the Government Stationery Office here to be forwarded addressed to you at Pickerel, Ont.

We note that you expect the repairs to the building to be completed at an early date. We hope that, when this building is ready, it will provide ample facilities and be quite satisfactory for the purpose. At a later date we will consider the lining of the ceiling and interior walls with V joint sheeting.

If you consider that the school should be opened as soon as the classroom is ready and the furnishings arrive, it will be necessary to obtain the services of a teacher, and I shall be pleased if you will endeavour to obtain a suitable person for this purpose. The name, qualifications and experience of any applicant for the position should be forwarded for the consideration of the Department. The salary allowed will depend upon the qualifications of the teacher secured.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,

Sir:

I have your letter of the 11th instant, enclosing a communication from Miss Louise B. Dale, teacher of the Lower French River Indian Day School, requesting that a boat be purchased to convey herself and the pupils to and from the school.

In reply I beg to say that as the season is now late it is considered that the providing of accommodation of the kind asked for could very well be postponed until next spring. However, if you are convinced that the purchase of the boat mentioned by the teacher is absolutely necessary to prevent any danger to the pupils who have to cross the river, you may use your discretion as to whether you make the purchase or not. If the boat is purchased, some arrangement will have to be made to have it properly stored during the winter. Please inform the Department of the action taken by you. Sir,

In reply to yours of November 9th (22-6), I wish to state that I visited Canton Island in company with Chief Moses Missable and inspected the building which you mentioned in your letter. It is very nicely situated and with some repairs would make a suitable school-house. I offered the Indian who owns the building $70.00 for it subject to the approval of the Department and he will sell for that sum. The building is worth $100.00 being a pine log building built on a stone foundation. It will be necessary to build a brick chimney and the roof will have to be re-shingled also a new floor, some glass and the chinks between the logs require to be plastered up. It would also be well to whitewash the building inside and outside and believe that all these repairs can be accomplished at a cost of around $200.00. The labour can be procured on the island. The crossing can be made at all times of the year except in the fall when the river is freezing and in the spring at the break-up.

None of the officials of the Pine Lake Lumber Co. were in camp when I called so I could not take up the matter of voluntary assistance with them at this time.

The teacher could board at the boarding house or she could stay in the upper part of the school-house and board herself.

I strongly recommend the purchase of this site as the school is urgently required and this building can be made suitable for school purposes within the cost designated in your letter. Trusting that this is satisfactory, I have the honour to be, Sir:

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

I have to report that on a recent visit to Lower French School, on inspecting the outside of the school building, which is an old log building, I found that it is in need of repair. The window frames are so decayed that they will hardly hold the glass and in a few cases the glass is held by tacks. The inside of this building is only lately completely lined with British Columbia dressed V jointed fir with two coats boiled oil and it looks well. The log part of the building has to be lime-washed at least once a year to make it look decent. I would recommend that to modernize the lighting of the school, that a new lighting system be put in, that is that the school be lighted with the light coming over the left shoulder of the pupil and that for the preservation of the log part of the building that it be clap-boarded and given two coats of paint. Should permission for these needed repairs be granted the building would be good for school purposes for 25 or 30 years.

The enclosed is an estimated cost of material and labour for repairs as stated.

Trusting that the Dept. will give this their earnest consideration.

I have the honour to be,

Sir:

Mr. Agent Daly, Parry Sound, requests that certain repairs be made to the Lower French River School building. This is an old log building. He recommends that new window frames be installed, some changes made in the position of the windows in order to have the light come over the left shoulder of the pupils, and the sides of the building clapboarded over the logs and given two coats of paint. The estimated cost of the work, including material and labour, is $551.90. He states that, should these repairs be carried out, this building would be good for school purposes for the next twenty-five or thirty years.

I would add that last summer we built a teacher's residence in connection with this school, and it is desirable that the school building be repaired, painted and placed in good condition. Funds for the purpose can be provided from Band Funds. The interest to the credit of the Band at the present time amounts to $4,725.80 and to the credit of Capital Account, $48,840.16. If you approve, the necessary authority will be given Mr. Daly to carry out the work.

Supt. of Indian Education.
Ottawa, July 11th, 1927.

Sir:

Referring to your letter of March 14th, last, relative to the repairs required to the Lower French River Day School building, I beg to say that you may have the work as mentioned in said letter carried out during the present summer holidays. The interior of the building should be clapboarded and given two coats of paint. The lighting arrangements should be altered so that the light will come over the left shoulder of the pupils. New window frames should also be installed, and any other work required to place this building in good condition should be carried out.

You should arrange for the purchase of all material required after obtaining competitive prices, if possible, and you should also arrange for the labour required under the charge of a competent foreman. Proper time sheets, in duplicate, should be kept, a supply of which is enclosed herewith for the purpose. The estimate which you submitted for the material and labour to the amount of $51.90 should not be exceeded, and, if possible, it should be carried out at less expense. The Department will expect you to oversee the work and see that it is satisfactorily carried out. Should you require an advance to pay the labour, the same will be sent you upon request. You should forward accounts, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the cost of the material and time sheets, in duplicate, also properly certified, for the labour employed.

Please give the matter of these repairs your early attention in order that they can be completed before the school reopens after the present summer holidays. The Department will leave this matter in your hands to have these repairs carried out to the best advantage and at the lowest possible expense.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,

Dear Mr. Ferrier,

I have seen Miss Caspar settled in her school, and, if I am any judge of character, I think I have got a pretty fine teacher. She seems to be a student from the amount of books that she had, and it just happens that there is no place to keep books. Some of them are pretty well bound. She has asked me if she could have some shelving put up.

She is satisfied with the quarters, but I am afraid that we will have to get a couple of mattresses. You will remember that the mattresses were bought from the Pine Lake Lumber Company, and I know by remarks passed by my daughter that they must be getting pretty well through. I examined one of them. They are straw, and I would recommend that two flock mattresses would be bought as the straw is pretty well worn in the mattress there.

I could get an Indian there to put up the shelving. It would only be plain inch shelving, and battens would not cost very much, with a little shellac to finish it off. I think it could be done inside of $10.00.

Your early consideration will be appreciated.

Yours truly,

Sir:

The Separate School Inspector, in a report on his recent inspection of the Lower French River Indian Day School, recommends that the closets be cleaned and placed in a sanitary condition and that screened approaches be provided. He also states that the school grounds are rough and unfenced.

I have to request that you will arrange to have the closets thoroughly cleaned and placed in a sanitary condition before the extreme cold weather sets in. You may also arrange to have proper screened approaches erected. All costs should be kept as low as possible.

With reference to the levelling of the grounds and the fencing of same, it is considered that this matter could stand over until next spring. You should, at that time, draw the attention of the Department to this matter, giving full particulars as to the work required to be done in the levelling of the grounds, the quantity of fencing required, and the approximate cost of any work recommended by you to be carried out.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

Replying to yours of Nov. 8th 22-6-5 re the Separate School Inspectors report of the Lower French River Indian Day School. It would appear by the Inspector's report that the Agent was not on the job. I respectfully beg to differ with the Inspector about the sanitary condition of the closets. They were never intended to have screens on them and unless I get a direct order to put screens on, I wont do so.

The grounds of the school are very much better than the grounds of the Public School which is across the River. With all due respect to the Inspector I will do nothing to the levelling of the grounds at any time, and would suggest that Mr. Perrier the Superintendent of Indian Schools of the Department, or one of his officials would visit this school. I am proud of the fact that out of a log house, about seventy years old with the Department's help I have made a school that is fit for inspection by any inspector.

The idea of fencing the grounds or levelling them in any way is foolish in my estimation. I would like the Department to understand that I mean foolish.

The school is one of the most sanitary schools of any rural school in Ontario. I will welcome any of the Department officials to the School to come and inspect this school, grounds and toilets. Without any Inspector's advice this school was started and as stated before in my letter I am proud of this school. The children were like little rabbits when I went there, now they have been prepared and are on a fair way to receiving an education.

I trust I will be understood by the Department, in these remarks, and before I am criticized I would like a member of the Department see the school and grounds before anything is done.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

Sir:

I have to report that when on a recent visit of inspection to Pickeral, Lower French, in looking at the school teacher's boat, I found that it is unseaworthy and not fit to be repaired again. It would be absolutely necessary to get a boat for the purpose of the teacher ferrying over from Contin Island to the School. This boat is also used for bringing the children over to the school, from the mainland.

Since my inspection, I have made enquiries about a boat owned by Mr. Graham of the Lumber and Ties Company, at Lower French. I have been in communication with him, and he informs me that he will sell his boat for $25.00. This boat, in my opinion is suitable and is a good bargain, and as it is in the storehouse at Pickeral there will be no freight to pay.

I would recommend that the boat be purchased from Mr. Graham as it is absolutely necessary to have it right away. The consideration of the Department by return mail is urgently requested.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

EXTRACT FROM LETTER OF J. M. DALY, ESQ., INDIAN AGENT,
PARRY SOUND, ONT., DATED SEPTEMBER 26, 1931.

While at Lower French School I looked the situation over re a boat and the dock. There is no dock there. There is a floating platform, which I must give Mrs. Munson credit for. She has had it moved down to the river. When I was there before it was high and dry. There are a lot of round boulders and the water is shallow where they have to land. As the water is low at the present time this is a good time to have this work done. I have given instructions that a place 12 feet wide be cleared and sufficiently far out in the river so that in the event of a blow coming up in the river the boat will be away from the rocks. I should explain that the river is wide here and squalls at this time of the year will come up and blow the boat away from the dock which causes it to hit these rocks. I observed that Mrs. Munson had the boat tied, bow and stern to the platform, but when the platform is floating it moves too, so you can quite easily understand how it is possible for a boat to be pounded against the rocks.

I have satisfied Mrs. Munson that the boat will be seaworthy for this season, so will try to keep this expense down until next Spring, but it will be necessary to have a good boat next spring. I will make arrangements with Scotts Boat Livery for a good strong boat which has been very slightly used and that I can procure for $50. This is a bargain that I am getting because of the business that I give to Scotts Boat Livery. The boat is well worth $75. This expenditure for boat can go into next year's estimates.

Sir;

Replying to yours of August 27th, 22-6-5, re woodshed for Lower French School. I decided the cheapest way to build a shed here is to make a lean-to on the north side of the school, and so that all the building will be uniform it will have to be done with clapboards, no other sheeting used.

As it is so late in the season I would not attempt to paint it this year, and as I will be making application for the painting of the teacher's house for the March estimates, I think the woodshed will do all right without paint until then. Following is as close an estimate as I can get. I may be a little out in the transportation for the material from Parry Sound to Pickeral Station on the C.P.R., it will have to be trucked to the river and taken across the river. It may amount to more than $10.00 but I figure that $10.00 will cover it.

I thought perhaps I could get along without putting up this woodshed, but I find that the Indians have been pilfering the wood, I think for use in the church and other places, and quite considerable of the wood has disappeared.

I think the time is opportune to get this done now. I have taken the matter up with a young man who is living at Pickeral and understands this work, and who is unemployed at the present time. I think it would be a good chance to go ahead and get this work done now. I don't think we will ever be able to get it done as cheap as at the present time.

Would the Department please let me know if we can go ahead with this work at the earliest opportunity?

Sir;

Enclosed please find pay sheet for work done on the woodshed at Pickeral. I examined this shed yesterday, it is finished and I am satisfied with the work done.

While at Lower French, I had conversation with Mrs. Munson, whom I might state is getting along extraordinarily well both with the Indians and with the whites. There has been sufficient clapboards left there which would make a porch for the back door, which is on the north side of the house. This has always been a sore part with the teachers, having no protection from the north wind on that door.

I would be in favour of a porch being built and as there is sufficient clapboards there to do it and we can get it done with cheap labour with the addition of flooring and roofing; this porch could be made very cheaply. Although I know that costs should be kept down, I think by doing this now we will be saving money. I think with the lumber required and the wages that the porch could be built for $85.00. I would strongly recommend that this be done.

I have made arrangements for the cutting of the school wood, and will submit the bills for the wood when delivered and piled in the shed. Trusting this will be satisfactory.

Sir:

I have your 3548 of the 13th instant, with reference to the new boat for the teacher at the Lower French River Indian Day School. The boat which the Department has purchased weighs only 130 pounds, and I doubt if it will be of much use for transporting children as a regular practice. Your letters of September 26th and October 15th, last, would indicate that the teacher's boat was not generally used for ferrying children. The Department's understanding is that the caretaker is paid at the rate of $5 a month for this service.

The boat which is supplied is really for the teacher at the school, but, of course, it can be used in emergencies for any legitimate departmental purpose. When making purchase, if the Department had had in mind the ferrying of the children, it would have been necessary to secure a much larger boat. As the ferrying arrangements had already been completed, it was the needs of the teacher largely that were considered when purchase was made.

Sir:

Replying to yours of July 9th, 29-6-5 with reference to the voucher amounting to $1.75 for A. N. Fenn, Parry Sound, in connection with supplies for the Lower French Indian Day School, the reason for me incurring this expenditure of $1.00 for a soft ball, was because the teacher, Mrs. Munson, was very anxious to get a ball for a field day the Band were holding and there was really no time, from the time she asked me to get the ball for her, to send to the Department and receive a requisition in time, so I got the ball here to try and fulfil her requirements.

The ball was not authorized by official letter of May 13th. I realize that the playground equipment is supplied direct from the Department, and I had no intentions to, or never will, try to appropriate the rule of the Department. I intended to send a covering letter explaining all about this ball, but I have been busy, very busy, looking into relief cases and trying to straighten out a lot of the tangles in this Agency at the present time. There seems to be a lot of unrest among the Indians here which keeps me on the jump mostly all the time, so I forgot to send a covering letter.

If the Department cannot see their way clear to pay for this ball, and I would not blame them if they did, because I should have sent that covering letter, would they please drop me a little note to that effect, strike out the dollar on the form, and I will pay for it the same as I did for the swing at Moosa Deer Point. The Department has nothing
to do with the swing because I promised that to
the children myself, but this ball was requested
on the bounce and was sent out on the bounce, but
there was no intention on my part of bouncing the
Department.

Trusting this will be satisfactory.

I have the honour to be,
Sir,
Your obedient servant,

Agent.

Sir:

While on a visit to Lower French Reserve last night, I had a talk with the Teacher, Mrs. Munson, and arranged with the caretaker of the school to see that the gasoline boat was put under proper cover during the winter.

Mrs. Munson apparently seems to be able to get along without any advice. She made application for a reading lamp and seemed disappointed that she did not get it. I told her that the Department was cutting down expenses and I did not think she would be able to get the lamp as she apparently could get along without it. She said she would requisition for it again.

She also asked for Cod Liver Oil for the children, and she has a line of talk which apparently is quite interesting so far as her care of the children is concerned. I told her the Doctor looked after these things, but that I would notify the Department of her wishes. She also informed me that the Inspector, Mr. Bennett had been there and was delighted with her work. I was remembering the advice that I got while at the Department while talking to her, and it was just as well, because she has a line of talk that I would not put up with for five minutes. I do not know how she talks any time she has been at the Department, but if she talked to the officials of the Department the way she talks to me, I am sure they would find that they were not hardly required, she can get along without any person.
I will appreciate it very much if the Department will have another place for this woman, at the end of the June term. She is not at all suitable for this Agency.

All arrangements have been made for the housing of the boat, and it is just possible there might be a small fee asked. There was not any fee asked, but it was hinted to me that there might be a small fee asked for the housing of the boat for the winter.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Sir:

I regret to have to state that I am still waiting for Mrs. Munson's bill. On December 8th I wrote to Mrs. Munson sending her an order to purchase goods to the value of $4.00 for the Christmas Tree, and stated that the grant was reduced because of lack of funds.

Ottawa, May 10th, 1935.

Dear Dr. McGill:

I inspected the Parry Sound Agency on the 25th-26th ultimo and beg to submit the following report.

Lower French River School

Needs painting. If possible this should be done this summer. The front steps are badly worn and should be replaced. A cupboard for the classroom is needed badly. There is no accommodation whatever for school supplies.

Thos. Mc Cookin.
Inspector.
Ottawa, May 20, 1933.

Sir:

Mr. Inspector McGookin, who recently visited the Lower French River Indian Day School, states that the school building needs painting and that, if possible, the work should be done this summer.

In this connection I would refer you to a previous communication regarding the painting required at the Ryerson Indian Day School, in which you were informed the Department would have no funds to carry out any painting of school buildings during the present fiscal year.

The Inspector further reports that the front steps are badly worn and should be replaced, also that a cupboard for the classroom is required, as there is no accommodation whatever for school supplies. I would request that you forward an estimate of the cost of replacing or repairing the front steps and the installing of a cupboard in the classroom. If this work is authorized, it could be carried out during the coming summer holidays.

Your obedient servant,

T. R. L. MacInnes,
Acting Secretary.

J. M. Daly, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Parry Sound, Ont.
Dear Mr. Daly,

You have asked me to keep you posted on such matters so, in your information, I wish to advise that there has been no ferrying of the children from the other side as yet this year. Moreover, the caretaker, Mr. Gailwayogai, has made no attempt to ferry the children.

In his position as Trustee, I asked him to speak to the parents about sending their respective children just as soon as their health would permit (they have had severe colds). Instead of conveying this message or speaking in a way befitting a Trustee Officer, he apparently informed them that "there were not enough children crossing to bother about and that he was not taking so few for nothing, it didn't pay." He had already told me the same thing, so then I called on the families personally and told them to send the
children to the point as soon as Monday morning and I would ferry them myself back and forth for as long as it was necessary.

This is not a practical thing to steady diet because the boat is too light in construction for children bouncing in and out but managing it myself, I can probably keep them from being too rough.

Tom has always disliked the ferrying of the children, has balked on it constantly, suggesting that the parents take the job. He has been in Bechuanon all this week so beginning Monday, I shall ferry the children for as long as necessary.

Would you also please make arrangements for having the dock reinforced?

Also, how about my stove; I would like you to have a look at it, I believe it will need new gaskets as well as its new lining?

Respectfully,

[Signature]

I cannot understand why Thomas Gakosheyongai would act in this manner because I know that he is getting goods in the store on the strength of the money that will be coming to him for ferrying.

I have written to Mrs. Munson telling her that the most important part of this transaction is to get the children ferried across the river, and that if Gakosheyongai does not function it will be all right for her to look after the children.

Sir:

Replying to yours of May 20th 22-6-5,

re the visit of Inspector McCookin to the Lower French Indian Day School, and his recommendation re the painting of the school, teacher's house, and toilets, the Department promised to send me a list of the schools this year that would be painted, but I presumed according to the grant, that this work could not be done this year. I would like to state for the information of the officials of the Department, that it is really time that these schools were painted but we will endeavour to get along without it this year.

Re the front steps at the school being in need of repair, as this is just a small platform, I will endeavour to get enough lumber around there, and get it patched up to do for the present and later on when there are more funds we will get a new platform made.

Re a cupboard being required for accommodating school supplies, there is a desk in the school with drawers which is quite suitable for holding the books and can be used for that purpose. Later on when there are more funds we can have a small cupboard made from tongue and groove lumber. In the meantime, I think we can get along without any expense.

Trusting this will be satisfactory.

Sir;

Replying to yours of May 23rd, 22-6-5 re the ferrying of the children to the school at Lower French Reserve, this matter has been settled up, and I found on arriving at Lower French that the dock and all the complaints that had been made were not exactly correct, and that the teacher and the caretaker Thomas Gaikeshayongai, were co-operating to give service.

Re the repairs to the step, I have to state that in mine of May 22nd, T.-5165, I reported that I had instructed the caretaker to use some lumber that is up there to fix up the step.

We can also get along without a cupboard, as stated in mine of May 22nd, T.-5165.

Re the repairs, to the stove; What is required is a brick lining and a shaker handle, the total cost of which should not exceed $5.00. The merchant cannot give me the exact amount. The caretaker can take out the burned brick and replace it with the new.

RESOLUTION NO. 2.

Moved by Sam Missabie,
Seconded by Charles Missabie,

That the Lower French Reserve day school building and teacher's residence be moved from its present site on Contin Island to a new site to be chosen on the Mainland.

Parry Sound, Ont., Jan. 4, 1943.

RESOLUTION NO. 2.

The Lower French Reserve Day School was built on Contin Island in the Pickerel River, where the majority of the Indians originally resided, but most of them have of late years moved over onto the mainland and there are now only five pupils attending the school who actually reside on the island and the family to which two of these belong will be moving to the mainland next spring. It has been suggested that the school and teacher's residence could be moved bodily across the ice during the winter. This would be an expensive job and I am not sure that it would not be just as well, if any move were considered, to erect new buildings. In the present state of public finances I do not like to recommend such an expenditure but it is a fact that the present situation of the school has a good deal to do with its poor attendance record.

Samuel Devlin
Indian Agent.
Ottawa,
January 6, 1943.

EXD.

Mr. S. Devlin, Indian Agent, Parry Sound, Ont.

I have your letter of the 4th instant, in connection with the Lower French River Indian Day School. There will be no funds available in next year's appropriation for the erection of a new building.

However, the Department is interested in the possibilities of moving the present buildings to a new site. You should make immediate inquiries and advise me at what cost you could have the two buildings moved and also the best date to move them. It is just possible that Mr. Arneil, Inspector of Indian Agencies, will have an opportunity of visiting your Agency within the next few weeks, but the information requested in the first part of this letter should be supplied immediately in order that we may discuss the matter further with Mr. Arneil before he goes to Parry Sound.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Parry Sound, Ont.

Pikelel, Ont.
March 23rd, 1943

Mr. S. Devlin
Parry Sound, Ont.

Dear Sir:

Further to your conversation with our Mr. Smith, we are prepared to undertake the job of moving the Indian Day School and teacher's residence from their present site on Contin Island to a new site to be designated by you on the mainland of the Lower French Reserve. The transfer of the buildings to be carried out by us before the ice leaves the Pikelel River this Spring. We agree to do this job for a maximum price of two hundred dollars ($200.00).

Yours truly,

Bill Clark Francis, Limited
Per: [signature]
Branch Manager
Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa, Ontario.

File No. 22-6-5.

Referring to your letter of January 6 with reference to a change of site for the Lower French River Indian Day School, I have been endeavouring to interest some responsible party in the job of moving the school buildings to a site on the mainland.

Trottier Bros., who were in the lumbering business at that point, had been promising to undertake the job and give me an estimate of cost, but their business has recently been taken over by their principals, Hill Clark Francis Limited, as Trottier Bros. have become insolvent. I talked with their local manager, Mr. Smith, while on a visit to the Reserve yesterday and he advised me that there should be a period in their operations shortly when they would have some men and teams available and he would be glad to undertake the job of moving the school. He is of the opinion that the sum of $200.00 would cover all contingencies and I am enclosing herewith his written offer to carry out the transfer of the buildings for that sum.

However, after talking to him, I discussed the proposed move, before leaving the Reserve, with some of the older Indians there and they advise me that the building was at least sixty years old, having been originally a log building, which had been, within comparatively recent years, renovated to serve as a schoolhouse by clapboarding on the outside and a matchboard finish on the inside. This being the case, there is a possibility that the old timbers in the
building may have decayed to such an extent that it would collapse if it were jacked up for moving. The only way we could prove this would be to start the process of jacking up the building and, if we found that it was unsafe to continue, we could let it remain on the present site.

Attendance at this school has been very poor during the winter, due to the extraordinary weather conditions which have prevailed and there is no question but that if the school were on the mainland the situation would be greatly improved.

I would be glad to have your further advice on this as quickly as possible, as the time during which the building could be moved across the ice is now limited.

Samuel Devlin,
Indian Agent.
Ottawa,
March 27, 1943.

EX'D.

Mr. S. Devlin, Indian Agent, Parry Sound, Ont.

I have your letter of the 24th instant, with reference to changing the site of the Lower French River Indian Day School. I feel that you should immediately commence the process of jacking up the building with a view to ascertaining if it can be moved. If so, you may make arrangements with Hill Clark Francis Limited to move it. It is noted that in the event of the building being moved the total expenditure will not exceed $200.00.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
REPORT ON PARRY SOUND INDIAN AGENCY FOR THE MONTH OF MARCH, 1943.

School attendance has been more than usually bad during the winter, due largely to the exceptional snow fall and cold weather. I am glad to be able to note that during the month a teacher was obtained for the Ryerson day school on the Parry Island Reserve. This school had been closed since last June and as it serves a good number of pupils, I am glad to see it in action again. There is a scheme on foot also to have the school buildings on the Lower French Reserve moved from their present site on Contin Island over to the mainland, which, if we can manage it, should make an improvement in the school attendance at that point.

Samuel Devlin,
Indian Agent.
Ottawa,
July 3, 1943.

Mr. S. Devlin, Indian Agent, Parry Sound, Ont.

On March 27 last I wrote to you and authorized you to move the Lower French River School to a new site. On reviewing our files I do not appear to have heard anything further from you since that time. Please let me know what action you took in this matter.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa, Ontario.

File No. 22-6-5.

I acknowledge receipt of your letter of July 3 with reference to moving the Lower French Reserve Day School to a new site. I had been under the impression that I had made a report on this matter some time ago but find that I have overlooked doing so and tender apologies.

The only chance of moving this school is across the ice during the winter. I had made arrangements with a lumber concern operating in the neighborhood who were the only available parties capable of doing the job, to have this carried out and they proposed to do it in the early spring, when their bush work would be completed and they would have the necessary horses and equipment available. It happened, however, that by the time they were prepared to undertake the job, ice conditions in the River made it impossible.

I propose to take the matter up again at the next suitable opportunity.

Samuel Devlin,
Indian Agent.
Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa, Ontario.

I request an advance of $84.90 to pay for alterations to the Moses Missabie house on the Lower French Reserve which I have been fitting up to serve as a school house. This considerably exceeds my estimate of $50.00 for this job but a number of items developed in the course of repair work which had not been foreseen. The amount also includes the transportation of the school equipment and a supply of wood from Contin Island to the mainland. This advance will be accounted for by receipts and labour return in the usual manner.

Samuel Devlin,
Indian Agent.

I wish to refer to your letter dated October 1, 1943 with reference to the payment of rental for building on the Lower French Reserve to be used as a day school. This building formed the sole assets of the estate of the late Moses Missable of the Heney Inlet Band, whose heirs are Lot Missable aged 20 and Grace Missable aged 17. Lot Missable is now in the Canadian Army overseas and his sister Grace was, until recently, a pupil of the Chapleau Residential School from where she was discharged last year and a situation found for her, I believe, in Ottawa.

Under these circumstances, I believe that the proper procedure would be to put this rental money in savings for these two minors until they attain their majority or wish to claim it. A savings account is already established for Grace Missable, into which her Annuity and Interest payments have been paid since her father's death.

I am therefore enclosing vouchers covering the rental of the building up to the end of the fiscal year which I hope is the correct procedure.

Samuel Devlin,
Indian Agent.
Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa, Canada

$69.00

The school inspector has recommended that another window should be cut in this building as the lighting is bad. A bridge over a small creek in front of the school for which the 2 x 8 plank is required has been broken down by stray horses and is in a dangerous condition.

Samuel Devlin

Mr. Samuel Devlin, Indian Agent, Parry Sound, Ont.

We appreciate very fully the difficulty experienced by our agents these days in securing the help necessary for the repair of schools. May we express the hope that these repairs will be undertaken in the future during the regular holiday period.

I am enclosing estimates of repairs necessary to the various schools in this Agency. Some of these estimates may appear high but the fact is that various repairs which were put off during the war years have accumulated.

The largest amount is for the Gibson Day School, the bulk of which is for fencing the school grounds and the erection of two new toilets. Authority was granted last year for these toilets to the amount of $112.00. I was unable to proceed with the work last year due to both the shortage of material and labour. I propose, if possible, to have it done this summer but a review of the situation shows the costs to be considerably increased due to prices of both material and labour.

I would be glad to have these costs for the various schools passed if at all possible but should it not be possible to pass on the amounts requested because of non-inclusion in the estimates, you might indicate what amounts would be available for expenditure on the various schools and I will have as much as possible completed this year and the balance next year. I am requested to obtain transportation daily for Marion Beaucage, daughter of Mrs. Frank Missabie of the Henvey Inlet Band. The situation is that these people are living at French River and this child is attending our Indian Day school at Pickerel on the Lower French Reserve. The distance between the two points is about five miles and the girl travels down on the morning train and back in the afternoon after school.

I understand that the Provincial authorities have some method of handling this in the case of white pupils and would be obliged if you could advise me as to how it might be managed in our case.

Samuel Devlin,
Indian Superintendent.
Mr. Samuel Devlin, Superintendent,
Indian Agency, Parry Sound, Ontario.

We have your letter of May 17th with reference to payment of transportation of Marion Beaucage.

This is an unusual case and while the cost is probably small, we may be setting a precedent if we approve.

Is she the only Indian child that finds it necessary to use train transportation to and from school daily? In what grade is she? Is there a white school closer to her home at which she could attend?

Bernard F. Neary
Superintendent of Education.
Dear Doctor Bennett:

Your letter of May 12th was awaiting me when I returned from a recent inspection trip on Manitoulin Island.

I visited the Spanish School and had a chance to talk to Harry Whiskeychan. He seems to be quite happy there and his only worry is that he be given an opportunity of visiting his parents on Hudson Bay this year. I am taking this matter up with the Indian Health Service to see if this can be arranged.

I am writing to our local Agent with regard to your letter and plan about the Pickerel school. Our big problem there is that undoubtedly the Indian Affairs Committee is going to recommend that we do not in future build separate Indian schools where Provincial schools are available. This is, of course, confidential as yet but the tendency is to have the Indian children educated as much as possible along with whites with whom they are going to have to live in future years. However, each situation has to be considered as a separate problem and we will certainly do what we can at Pickerel.

We have just had our new salary schedule approved by Treasury Board. Teachers with second class certificates will have a range of from $1,440. to $1,920. Teachers with first class certificates will have a range
of from $1,500. to $2,220. If you run across any Catholic teachers who are interested in teaching Indians, either in Ontario or in the West, I would be only too glad to have you give them my address so that I can send them application forms.

We are particularly short of Catholic teachers in British Columbia and are only too glad to have teachers with certificates granted by such a fine province as Ontario.

Yours sincerely,

Bernard F. Neary
Superintendent of Education.

J.M. Bennett, M.A., Ph.D.,
Inspector of Separate Schools,
47 Browning Ave.,
Toronto 6, Ontario.

Suggestions for building Indian School at least possible cost.

1. One floor only.

2. No cellar - concrete foundation at least 3 ft. below ground level and 1/2 ft. above with small screened air holes to keep air dry under the floor and keep animals out (mice, etc.).

3. Use undressed 2" x 6" planks for joice about one ft. apart to assure a solid floor and braced.

4. A double floor with building paper between (spruce flooring and well painted (3 coats) unless you can get hardwood or square tile which we now use in Toronto.

5. (a) Studding, dressed
   (b) Use hemlock undressed, if you wish on the studs. Then building paper and then the outside siding which could be dressed siding or imitation insul board to assure a warm room.

6. The inside walls to be ten test or donnacona board and stripping over the seams, but not beaver board (which they used at Christian Island). Same for ceiling. This ten test will keep the heat in the room and will assure a cooler room in hot weather.

7. Have a good brick chimney.

8. A box stove will give plenty of classroom heat.

9. Roofing - use asphalt squares on shiplap.

10. Ordinary classroom windows will do since the attendance isn't large and it will be easier to heat. While it is an excellent idea to have the most possible window space yet that isn't necessary with a small enrolment as this school will have.

11. Have space between kitchen and bed-sitting room about 7 ft. wide to assure heat in the bedroom. A good kitchen range set midway would heat both rooms.

12. Build a woodshed at the same time to save cordwood from deterioration by the weather and in one corner of it build the teacher's toilet to one side of the entrance.

Sir,

Enclosed please find rough sketch of proposed house for school teacher at Lower French Reserve, also wholesale prices on material from Rogers' mill, Parry Sound.

I should state that I can cut this material bill down about $150.00 by purchasing rough lumber at Pickeral. I have included a cellar in the building because a small pipeless furnace can be used which is the most economical for heating purposes. I would draw your attention to the fact that this District will soon be back to its original state and in my opinion, it's advisable to have a comfortable home for the teacher, to get the best results. This building, as I see it finished, will be about the same as the one at Shawanaga except that it will have a cellar which will do for storing wood and will thus do away with the necessity of having a wood-shed. There is need for a wood-shed for the school and this could be built at the same time at very little cost, as a lean-to to the school. I should state that the Band are very desirous of going ahead with the work and I am assured by the Chief and Council that they will make a Bee to help keep down the cost of labour. If they do this, the labour bill will not amount to $300.00 as quoted. I will be prepared to go ahead as soon as the Dept. says so. The members of the Band are awaiting the orders of the Dept. to start right away.

Trusting that this may receive the careful consideration of the Dept. and assuring them that I will give my best to see that a good job is done at the least possible cost.

I have the honour to be,

Your obedient servant,

J.D. McLean Esq.,
Secretary Dept. Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

October 17, 1925.

Mr. McLean,

The boarding house where the teacher of the Lower French River Indian Day School has resided heretofore has been closed indefinitely, due to the cessation of the operations of a lumber company. Mr. Indian Agent Daly strongly recommends that a small residence be built for the use of the teacher. The Indians of the Band have agreed to have a bee and the Agent can secure rough lumber quite cheap. Mr. Daly is of the opinion that he can erect a suitable building for approximately $550.

This day school is not important enough to warrant the provision of a good teacher's residence; and, as it is extremely desirable that some facilities be secured without delay, I wish to recommend that he be authorized to proceed with the work. Funds can be found in the Appropriation for Indian Education.
