Sir:

I have your T-576 of the 12th instant, with reference to a teacher's residence at the Lower French River Indian Day School. I note that you can purchase rough lumber, the necessary hardware, cement, etc., arrange for considerable labour on the part of the Band without cost and keep the total expense down to about $600. You may proceed with the work and explain to the Indians of the Band that authority is being directed because you and they are interested in getting the residence erected. They should give their labour freely, so that no unnecessary expense will be incurred.

I note that you can secure rough lumber very cheaply at Pickerel. If you are satisfied that better prices could not be secured, it will not be necessary to call for tenders in the regular way. Dear Mr. Ferrier:

Please find report of conditions of ice on the Pickeral River, which explains the situation fairly well. When I was paying the Spring payment, the ice was so poor that the Chief asked me to stop the Teacher from crossing over as it was dangerous. That morning the Teacher crossed and went over her rubbers, which were knee high. (I am explaining) I look for service from the teachers and I get it but in this case the teacher cannot give the proper service unless she have her own house on the Island.

When I made arrangements with the Indians about the teacher's house, they all said that they would build it on the community or barn-raising plan. I now find that they had no intention of doing so. The material is on the ground and part of the cellar is dug and I am starting two men on Thursday to go ahead. The only way I can build it now is by day labour. I have a bad cold at present and the Doctor says I'm to stay in bed for a few days, (I am not in bed) but I am trying to get clear of it. As soon as I can get around, I intend to go up to Pickeral for a week and get them started with some vim.

I would like, Mr. Ferrier, if you or some of the staff could pay us a call before this season closes or soon after the schools start in the Fall. I am persuaded that even with the good understanding and co-operation between this Agency and your Dept., that a better understanding of the difficulties to surmount in this Agency could be obtained by a visit.

Please do not think that we do not think that we don't get enough consideration. We have no complaint and are proud to serve your Dept. and would only like you or one of the staff to see the work that we are doing to further the interest of Education among the Indians under our care. Please say if I may put on a force of men and get the work started as soon as possible.

Trusting that the situation will be understood from this communication.

I have the honour to be,

Sir:
Your obedient servant,

Agent.

Dear Sir:

Enclosed please find pay sheets for work done on the teacher's house at Lower French Reserve, paid, signed and completed.

I should state that on my inspection this trip, I was almost crazy (What is, in a quiet way) when I saw the bungle of things they made. I must say that the Indians mean well and apparently work hard but quite a bit of their work is to no purpose and has to be repeated. If you were here, you would understand at a glance just what I mean. When I visit, I explain through the Chief, what is wanted and they say they understand and I go away thinking that they do then when I come back it would make an Angel swear to see how they do things. I have cut their wages five cents an hour to try to make the appropriation of $500.00 for labour on the building, spin out, but I'm sure that they won't finish in the time they said they would.

It was expected that they would have four or five "Bees," but up to the present time they haven't had any, and I'm sure they never intended to have any. Chief Wilson Ashawasagai doesn't seem to have very much control over the Band, although, according to talk, he would try to make you believe that he could get them to do anything.

I will forward a separate pay sheet for work done in levelling the cellar and digging the well, listed on sheet as well-digging, by the end of this week. This is a separate item. Most of the work done in this case has been levelling the cellar and around the outside of the house. The crib is made for the well and should be finished by next week. After I'm through with the Robinson Treaty payment, I will have more time to devote to this building and purpose going up for a week to see the building finished properly.

Trusting that this will be satisfactory,

I have the honour to be,

Sir:
Your obedient servant,

John McEwan
Agent.

P.S. Enclosed is pay sheet for well digging, this pay sheet is not paid yet, send cheque to cover amount.

Ottawa, December 30, 1926.

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of the voucher which you submitted in favour of Mr. W.H. Ferrar for installation of a hot air furnace, etc., at the teacher's residence on the Lower French River Reserve, and in reply I beg to direct your attention to the following remarks, namely:

The freight charge of $1.42 on the water tank should be supported by a receipt. A receipt should be supplied also in support of the express charge of $2.20 on plumbing tools, and the item "½ of fare Parry Sound-Pickerel" should be explained.

Expenses incurred in connection with this residence are large. Your estimate made in October, 1925, of $600.00 has been much exceeded. The vouchers before the Department indicate that labour has cost $583.65, material $1,215.76, and furnishings $241.59, making a total expenditure of $2,046.00.

You should report without delay stating whether you propose to present any further accounts in connection with this building for payment.

Your obedient servant,

J.D. McLean

Memorandum-

Mr Ferguson

Agent Daly reports that the Teacher's residence at Lower French River is now completed. The total cost of this job is $2042.06 - $392.06 of which was paid from School Vote, and the balance $1650.00 paid from the Band fund, Account 13.

Analysis of the vouchers paid from Trust Fund shows that labour was $588.65, building material $319.76 and furnishings $241.89.

When this building was started it was decided that the band could pay $450.00, and anything over this would be chargeable to School Vote, and I presume that the band funds can now be recouped for expenditure over that amount from the Vote for Indian Education.

Sir:

Following mine of the 21st ultimo, T-893, re-
washout at school house on the Lower French Reserve,
I have to report that I examined the damage and the
enclosed is a rough sketch of what I could see of it.
The cellar is full of wood and I could not examine
the whole of the wall. There were four feet of water
in the cellar, before they were able to get the water
out and there was about six inches of water in it
when I examined it. It appears to me that the Indians
made a poor mixture of cement on the lower part or
first part of the wall. The top part is good cement
but I can't be sure whether it was the water that did
the damage or not. It's a sorry looking mess and
before doing anything to it, the ground, north and
east of the foundation will have to be tiled to carry
away the water. It appears that in building, we have
blocked a series of springs, at least that is what the
Indians say. In the meantime, nothing can be done
until the water stops. I would suggest that it be
left until the repairs to the school are made in June,
then I could arrange to go up there with a man who
understands cement work and get it fixed up.

I need hardly say that I am annoyed about this
but it is something that I could not foresee. I sinc-
erely trust that I am wrong about the first part of
the cellar being a poor mixture—meantime, I have my
doubts. I should state that the house is built on a
slope. The top of the north wall, being about 10"
above the level of the ground, the ground gradually
sloping until there is about 5 ft of the south wall
above ground.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 22nd instant, relative to the repairs required to the foundation under the teacher's house at the Lower French River Indian Day School.

In reply I beg to say that, as agreed with you during your visit to the Department yesterday, you may arrange to have the necessary repairs to the foundation of this building carried out. Please forward properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, in the usual manner covering the cost of the material and for the labour.

Dear Mr. Ferrier,

I was at Lower French school the other night, and was surprised and annoyed at the condition of the furnace in the teacher's house. Perhaps you will remember that I spoke to you about this before. This was a second hand furnace and its usefulness is now over, for this reason:

When I went into the house there was smoke in the house, and when I asked Miss Casper what was the trouble, she said it had been smoking quite a lot recently. I went down into the cellar and examined the pipes and they seemed all right. I then came up to the sitting room and looked through the register and was quite alarmed when I saw little sparks coming out. The top of the pot is cracked, and it is not safe. I fixed it up with clay and sand.

I would suggest that in your estimates that you would allow for a new furnace. I have interviewed the William Beatty Company here, and have got the price of a furnace that would be suitable and guaranteed. The cost would be $105.00 and about $30. for installing. To explain the cost of installing there would have to be two men go to Pickeral Station, and the furnace would have to be taken from the station to the school which would be about two miles. If it was to be installed now, it would be much easier as it could be hauled on a sleigh over to the school. After the break up, it would be a lot more trouble taking it over, as that would mean two forms of transportation, by land and by water, and might cost a few dollars more.

You will remember that the furnace installed was a secondhand one, and it has turned out to be more second hand than I thought it was.

Your consideration at your earliest will be appreciated.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

Ottawa, January 31, 1930.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 28th instant, relative to the condition of the furnace in the teacher's house at the Lower French River Indian Day School, and recommending that a new furnace be supplied and giving an estimate of the cost of supplying and installing same.

In reply I have to say that our funds for the balance of the present fiscal year are completely assigned and, unless the matter is urgent, it will not be possible to provide for the cost of supplying and installing a new furnace at the present time. It is hoped that the furnace now in use can be made satisfactory for the balance of the present winter and that there will be no danger of fire in using same. We are making a note of the need of a new furnace for next winter's use at this school, and you will receive the necessary instructions and authority regarding the purchase and installing of same early next Summer. You might let me know if there would be any danger of fire in using the present furnace for the balance of this winter.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

J. M. Daly, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Parry Sound,
Ont.

The Secretary
Department Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Sir:

Replying to yours of Jan 31st, 22-6-5, re the furnace for the teacher's house at Lower French Indian Day School, I have to state that the teacher is nervous about the condition of the furnace, and I really don't blame her. I don't think it is safe. What the teacher is afraid of is that something might happen when she is sleeping and what might happen is too awful to think of.

What I could arrange for, is that I could get the furnace installed and the bill submitted after the estimates are passed. Please say if I can do this.

Your consideration at your earliest will be appreciated.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Agent.
Ottawa, February 5, 1930.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 3rd instant, in further reference to the supplying of a new furnace for the teacher's house at the Lower French River Indian Day School.

In this connection I have to say that, provided you can arrange that payment of the cost of supplying and installing the furnace be held over until our appropriation for the next fiscal year is available, you may purchase a new furnace of a type considered by you to be satisfactory for the heating of the teacher's house and also for the installation of same in a satisfactory manner. It is noted from your letter of the 29th ultimo that the cost of the new furnace would be approximately $105 and the installation of same about $30. You should see that a satisfactory job is completed in the installation of the furnace. You should forward an itemized account, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the expenditure incurred about the middle of April, next, when funds will be available for payment of the expenditure.

It is presumed from your letter of the 29th ultimo that the old furnace is unfit for further use, and you may dispose of same in any manner you wish.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

J. M. Daly, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Parry Sound,
Ont.

EXTRACT FROM LETTER OF MR. JOHN M. DALY, INDIAN AGENT, PARRY SOUND, DATED NOV. 14, 1931.

While at Lower French, I had conversation with Mr. Munson, whom I might state is getting along extraordinarily well both with the Indians and with the whites. There has been sufficient clapboards left there, which would make a porch for the back door, which is on the north side of the house. This has always been a sore part with the teachers, having no protection from the north wind on that door.

I would be in favour of a porch being built as there is sufficient clapboards there to do it and we can get it done with cheap labour with the addition of flooring and roofing this porch could be made very cheaply. Although I know that costs should be kept down, I think by doing this now we will be saving money. I think with the lumber required and the wages that the porch could be built for $25.00. I would strongly recommend that this be done.
Ottawa, November 19, 1931.

Sir:

Referring to that portion of your letter of the 14th instant regarding your recommendation that a porch be erected over the back door on the north side of the teacher's house at the Lower French River Indian Day School, I have to say that the Department will approve of you arranging to have this work done. It is noted that there are sufficient clapboards on hand to make the porch and that the cost of the work, including material and labour, will not exceed approximately $25.

Please arrange to have this work carried out before the extreme cold weather sets in, and when same has been completed, you should forward certified accounts, in duplicate, in the usual manner covering the cost of the labour and for any material it is found necessary to supply.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

J. M. Daly, Esq.,
Indian Agent,

Ottawa, November 21, 1931.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of the requisition which you forwarded from the teacher of the Lower French River Indian Day School for window blinds, curtain material, bedding, dishes, rugs, paint, etc., for the use of the teacher's living quarters.

In this connection I have to say that you may arrange for the purchase and delivery of the various supplies as asked for by the teacher on her requisition. This requisition is returned herewith for your information and guidance as to the supplies required. Besides the window blinds required for the residence, you may purchase 6 blinds, 32", for the school.

Regarding the rag rugs, it is considered that the expenditure for this purpose should not exceed $10 in the purchase of two small rugs.

Please keep all expense in purchasing these supplies as low as possible, and when same have been delivered, you should forward an itemized account, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the expenditure incurred.

You are being written in a separate communication regarding the classroom supplies, etc., for the school.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

J. M. Daly, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Parry Sound,
Ont.

Sir:

I have to report that while on a recent visit to the Lower French Reserve, on examining the pipes of the furnace in the teacher's house, I found that there are two lengths of pipe and two elbows required.

These have to be made of heavy metal as there is short draft to the chimney. I can have them made here in Parry Sound. It is necessary to have these pipes before October as the nights get cold up there around the end of September.

The Chief, Moses Missabie, whom I have great confidence in, discussed with me, the advisability of having cod liver oil for distribution at the school, as from his personal observation he has found this is a good thing and keeps the doctor from being called there, and as the cost of the doctor going up there is rather expensive, I would strongly advise that five gallons of cod liver oil be sent to the teacher to be distributed to the children by the Chief and the teacher as they see fit.

The immediate consideration of the Department in this will be very much appreciated. The cod liver oil can be sent direct to:- Miss Margaret O'Toole, School Teacher Lower French Reserve, Pickeral C.P.R., Pickeral, Ont.

Sir,

After serious consideration with the Chief and members of the Magnetawan Band at Byng Inlet, I was asked to put the matter before the Department of having a school on their Reserve.

There are 12 children now in the Reserve, who have had no schooling, and 3 who are attending the Public School at Byng Inlet. Before fall there are some 5 children who will be of school age before fall.

I have been making enquiries all winter re-this situation at Magnetawan, and I believe I could purchase a house large enough, which could be made suitable for school purposes.

This matter will have to be taken up some time and as the Chief says, the children have not had a fair show.

I would appreciate it if the Department would give this matter their very serious consideration.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 11th instant, regarding the request of the Chief and members for the establishment of a school for the benefit of the Indian children of the Magnetawan Band at Byng Inlet. It is noted that there are about 20 children of school age who would attend, provided a school was opened.

The Department is disposed to favourably consider the request made for the opening of a school at this point, and I shall be pleased if you will ascertain whether it would be possible to purchase a building that would be suitable for the purpose. If so, please state the cost of the same and the expense that would be involved in having it fitted up as a classroom. Also state whether it will be possible for a teacher to obtain boarding accommodation in the neighborhood or whether living quarters would have to be provided. Please ascertain from the band if they would be prepared to pay the whole or any part of the cost of purchasing a building and fitting up and furnishing it for school purposes.

On the occasion of your next visit, you should inquire as to what arrangements could be made, at the least expense, for the establishment of a school for the Indian children at Byng Inlet. The question of authorizing the fitting up and conducting of a school at this point will depend upon the expenditure involved. A report at your convenience, giving full particulars regarding the above, will be appreciated.

Sir,

The main building is built on a good cement foundation, the size being 25 by 16 with continuation of slanting roof kitchen 16 by 16. The studing are 2 by 6, and the building is double-sheeted and clapboard sheeting on outside. The ceiling is about nine feet high. The upstairs is all in one with a good pine floor down stairs, and upstairs.

The building was built in 1915 and is built on a rock, with commanding view, and very suitably situated for the purpose required.

The Naganesh family want $600.00 for the building and approximately 1/4 acres of ground which would be ample room for play ground.

I estimate the alteration with the painting could be done for about $300.00, as I am informed that I can secure all supplies at Byng Inlet less the paint, which I can do better by buying it here in Parry Sound.

I have made arrangements with members of the band to do the work in the event of the Department approving of going on with same.

I might say that upstairs could be converted into two good sized rooms for use of teacher, and I propose using part of the kitchen as a leak room, leaving a good sized kitchen for use of teacher, which should be enough for any teacher who might be there. The cellar has plenty of room for storing supplies.

Should the teacher desire to board, I am informed that arrangements can be made to have her board near the school.

The distance from the school to the Byng Inlet station is about 1½ miles.

I have the honour to be,

Sir:

Sir,

Answering yours of May 15th, 22-7-1, I have been to the Magnetawan Reserve, and met the band in council. They are very keen to have a school and passed the following resolutions:

(1) That the Department be asked to purchase the Naganesh house, for the purpose of converting it into a school house.

(2) That the band are not in a position to grant any money out of their funds and would pray that the Department consider their long-felt need and grant them the privilege of having a school on their reserve.

I might say that I saw some of the children at the Council meeting, as I had made arrangements to have them present, and they are a bright lot of boys and girls, and I'm sure the Department will not regret giving these children of the band the opportunity of obtaining an education.

Enclosed is a description of the building which, I believe, can be made into a comfortable little school, to suit the needs of the Band.

March 11th, 1924.

MEMORANDUM

MR. SCOTT,

Last summer Mr. Agent Daly, Parry Sound, forwarded a request from the Chief and members of the Maganetawan Band at Byng Inlet for the establishment of a school for the benefit of the Indian children residing at that point. There are about 20 children of school age who would attend providing a school is opened. The Agent states that he can purchase a house, which, with some repairs and alterations, would be suitable, and also one-half an acre of ground, for the sum of $600. He estimates the alterations and painting required would cost approximately $300. The size of the building is 25'x16', with a lean-to 16'x16'. There is an upstairs that could be fitted up and used for a teacher's living quarters. The Band have not sufficient funds at their credit to pay for the building and the fitting up of the same. We have included in our Estimates for the year 1924-25 the sum of $1000 for the purpose.

The Agent desires to be informed whether the Department intends to proceed with the establishment of a school at this point, as, if so, it will be necessary for him to make the purchase of the building at an early date. I would recommend that, as funds will be provided in next year's appropriation for Indian Education, the Agent be instructed to proceed with the purchase of the building and the fitting up of same as soon as weather conditions permit. There is no doubt that a school is required for the benefit of the Indian children on the Maganetawan Reserve, as at present they are without educational facilities. The Chief and members of the Band desire a school, and have promised to give their full support, and have guaranteed a regular attendance of the Indian children of school age.

Sir,

Replying to yours of March 13, 22-5-17.

I beg to state that I held a meeting of the Maganatowan Band on March 27. I went over the ground with an Indian who was to have done the work, measured it all, and plotted it down and had everything in readiness to forward to the Dept. when Mrs. Noganosh changed her mind and for family reasons refused to sell the house. It was not in regard to the money that she objected, but simply for family reasons and a desire to keep the place as long as she lives.

I explained to the Band that the Dept. was desirous of keeping their promise of last fall to the Band, and that they should arrange to get a piece of ground for school purposes.

This, the Band is considering and it is being arranged to have the portion of land next to the Noganosh place put aside for school purposes. One part of it, I am told, belongs to the Noganosh family and I understand that they will accept $50.00 for that part. The other part would be free, or in other words, the ground can be secured for $50.00.

I am not quite clear about just what to do, but should the Dept. approve, I will go ahead and build a new building after I get prices on the material. There are quite a few young children who will be gradually coming of school age each year, so that there can be no mistake about putting up a building.

I am informed and have found out, that the Band have not any place for worship, and they would like to have a building which would serve both purposes. I will endeavour to figure this out as cheaply as possible, should the Dept. wish this done. There could also be a small addition added to the main building for a residence for the school teacher, at very little cost.

Please advise me as to the wishes of the Dept. at your earliest, and I will get the particulars re-the land within the next 5 days.

Trusting that this will meet with the approval of the Department.

I have the honour to be,

Sir:

Your obedient servant,

Agent.

Pursuant to our telephone conversation this morning, I have to inform you that J. Carmichael, of Byng Inlet, lives on the Indian Reserve and for years his children have attended the Indian School there. The Provincial authorities are about to organize the white parents into a school board and will ask them to pay fees to the Indian school. Sir;

Replying to yours of June 16th, 22-8-1 referring to letter sent by Miss Edith M. Biasucci applying for appointment as teacher of the Magnetewan Indian Day School, in which you requested me to interview Miss O'Meara at once and ascertain her intentions as to her resigning from the school,-

Although very inconvenient to do so at the present time, I hustled around and caught the train, and interviewed Miss O'Meara. Enclosed please find her resignation. Miss O'Meara informed me that she had sent her resignation to the Department, how she came to do this I do not know, but according to her remarks I presume she had been instructed from the Department to do so. How she could be instructed to do this by the Department, I do not know.

I also made a point of interviewing Miss Edith M. Biasucci and she informed me that it was the Parish Priest who had interviewed Miss O'Meara and who had told her that Miss O'Meara was resigning, and that is the reason she applied personally to the Department for the school.

Enclosed please find copy of letter sent to me by Arthur G. Slaght, K.C. and Member of Parliament for Parry Sound, re this matter. The Provincial member, Dr. Armstrong is also interested in this girl getting this position, as well as the clergymen, the church, the officials of the railway, and I might state that it is an understood all around Britt that she is likely to get the appointment. I mention these facts that I found out last night so that the Department will understand that if Miss Biasucci is engaged as teacher of that school, it will be a popular appointment.
Enclosed please find a few suggestions regarding new teachers being engaged in this Agency, which I trust the Department will seriously consider.

I am still of the opinion that Miss Edith M. Biasucci will make a good teacher in Magnetawan Indian Day School.

Trusting this will be satisfactory.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Ottawa, June 26, 1924.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 20th instant, enclosing an application from Mrs. Taylor for the position as teacher of the new school at Maganetawan, together with a certificate from the Public School Inspector regarding her qualifications.

In reply I beg to say that the Department will approve of the appointment of Mrs. Taylor, to begin duties when the schools re-open after the summer holidays, on or about September 2nd, next. The salary allowed will be at the rate of $650 per annum, payable on a basis of ten teaching months in the year. This will be supplemented by any bonus provided by law, which during the present fiscal year, ending March 31st, next, will be at the rate of $15 per month. You will be good enough to inform Mrs. Taylor of her appointment and arrange with her to be at the school to commence duties on the 2nd of September, next. Kindly inform the Department as to whether or not she accepts the position.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

John M. Daly, M.D.,
Indian Agent,

Ottawa, August 15, 1931.

Sir:

I have to inform you that the Department has appointed Miss Gertrude O'Meara, of R.R. No. 1, Billings Bridge, Ont., to the position of teacher of the Maganetawan Indian Day School. Duties will commence on September first and salary at the rate of $90 per teaching month will be allowed. Miss O'Meara has a second class professional certificate and three years' successful experience in Ontario. I have promised her that you will write, giving her advice regarding reaching her school and where she will find the keys, etc. You might also inform her regarding the usual arrangements for the janitor and other services.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Memorandum:

REPRESENTATIVE OF THE TREASURY

Re: Magnetawan Indian Day School No. 404

The present teacher, Mrs. Rita Dupuis, has resigned, effective July 1, 1943, and no further salary should be paid to her after that date.

Philip Phelan,

Ottawa, July 6, 1943.

Mr. Samuel Devlin, Indian Agent, Parry Sound, Ont.

With reference to your letter of the 3rd instant the Department approves the appointment of Mrs. Emily Sharette as teacher of the Magnetawan Indian Day School for the academic year 1943-44.

Mrs. Sharette will be allowed a salary at the rate of $85.00 a teaching month plus bonus, effective September 1, 1943.

She should complete the inclosed forms, when she begins duties and you should forward these at that time.

In order to make certain that Mrs. Sharette will receive her salary at the end of September you should let me know before September 10, 1943, if she began her duties on September 1 and at the same time you should return the inclosed forms, properly completed.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Ottawa,
November 24, 1943.

Memorandum:

REPRESENTATIVE OF THE TREASURY

Re: Magnetawan Indian Day School
No. 404

The Department has appointed Miss Mary Margaret Hoffron as teacher of this school at a salary of $50.00 a teaching month, effective October 1, 1943. I enclose copy of letter of appointment, cost-of-living bonus form and staff questionnaire.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Ottawa,
May 3, 1944.

Memorandum:

REPRESENTATIVE OF THE TREASURY

Re: Magnetawan Indian Day School
No. 404

Please note that the teacher, Miss Margaret Reffron, is giving up duties at this school, effective June 1, and she should be paid salary for the month of May but not for the month of June. I understand that she will resume duties at this school for the academic year 1944-45; namely, from September 1, 1944.

for Deputy Minister.

Memorandum:

REPRESENTATIVE OF THE TREASURY

Re: Magnetawan Indian Day School
No. 404

As you were advised in memorandum of May 3, 1944, Miss Margaret Heffron gave up duties at this school on June 1, 1944. We are now informed that she will not resume duties at this school for the coming academic year.
